description:
It's still verging on perfection. I think this is my favourite Italian in SF. It's obviously not high end fancy dining, but the food is just GOOD. 
It's hard to get calamari right, but every time I get it here it's melt-in-the-mouth good. It's also grilled and not battered/fried like so much of the calamari in little Italy. 
I really enjoy that they make the pizza right in front of you, and I always try and sit at the bar which looks over the pizza oven area so I can watch in anticipation. The ingredients are just super simple and fresh and good. The BURRATA my god it is so creamy. My latest thing is getting the pizza topped with the burrata, which is creamy enough to dip your crusts into. You're welcome.
The only thing I'm sad about is the fact they removed the Yelp waitlist feature, and for that reason I wouldn't visit at peak times.
author: Poppy C.

description:
Here's the breakdown:
Real Rating: 4.5

1. This place is lit. As in, it's busy and crowded. Expect a wait if you come on a weekend during the usual dinner time. I went for a late dinner (9:30pm) on a Sunday and luckily for us, a table for two just opened up so we didn't have to wait. But the place was packed even at that time. 

2. The Prosciutto pizza was delicious ($18.75), the Lasagneria ($15) was okay. The pizza's dough was cooked perfectly where it had the perfect amount of chewy and crunchiness. The toppings were great and fresh. This pizza was just straight up amazing. The Lasagneria was a bit bland for my taste, but it was the only vegetarian pasta option and as my friend was vegetarian and craving pasta, that was our only choice.

3. The interior is nicely decorated. It's dim and dark yet romantic and fun. It does get a bit loud. It's a perfect place for a date or going out with a group (or a couple) of friends.

4. The service was okay. It did take the servers some time to take our order and they only checked up on us once, which I understand since it's busy. But the service didn't feel warm and welcoming. I kind of got a feel the servers didn't want to be there. This is the sole reason I couldn't hand out a 5-star rating, sadly.

5. The prices range from $16-19 for a pizza and is $15 for the lasagna. You can always add more topping to the pizza which hikes up the price. I think the prices are fair for what they provide. 

6. The crowd is young and lively. Expect a mixture of techies, hipsters, and just really fashionable people. It's a fun group of crowd.

Overall, I would recommend this place for their pizzas. So delicious and would definitely come back. I would recommend for a date or a small friend gathering. It's a bit crowded for a large group of people.
author: Shin L.

description:
Came here for lunch, the place was mostly packed around 1pm and we got seated right away. The place get a good breeze and shadow, so it stays cool. Service was very good from the beginning to the end.

We ordered one of their lasagnas, mozzarella cheeses, and a pizza. Everything came out very fast, and it was delicious. The Lasagna was really juicy and perfectly cooked. 

The cheese with flat breads and salad was delicious, wanted to lick the place to get all of the olive oil from it.

The pizza was also very delicious and the servers taking care of us made sure we always had water and everything else we needed.
author: Carlos P.

description:
If you love pizza and cheese (especially burrata), this place is your jam!

Bright, airy, and cheerful open-spaced restaurant located in the Financial District. Lots of seating available. Not super busy during lunchtime on Saturdays earlier in the afternoon. 

Il Casaro || $17.50 
Mozzarella, grana padana cheese, cremini mushrooms, San Daniele prosciutto. Add burrata +$4. I was craving burrata so obviously added it as another cheese to the pizza. This pizza is perfect to share between 2 hangry people or 3 relatively hungry folks! Crust is perfectly crisp and chewy. Generous portions of cheese, mushrooms, and prosciutto! The prosciutto is on the saltier side, so I almost felt like there were too many slices in proportion to the pie-- but if you love meat, you'll appreciate the serving cuts. The burrata adds an amazing creaminess to the experience!

Overall, I highly recommend trying out the burrata here! The pizzas are DELICIOUS. Would love to come back to try out Il Casaro's other offerings if I'm ever back in this area :)
author: Jennifer H.

description: I haven't had pizza in quite sometime, and I had a major craving for it. I'm super glad I found this place. Walked in around 4:00ish. No one was in there. Clearly not "peak time". Ordered the Diavola pizza. I added prosciutto ($4). They did NOT skimp out on toppings. This tends to happen at a lot of pizza places..and it drives customers away. Service was great. Fast. The waitress was sweet. Would recommend.
author: Olive R.

description: Ordered burrata, roasted cauliflower, and spicy coppa salumi apps, and the Calabrese and Brocolli and Salsicia pizzas.  The Burrata was amazing, the roasted cauliflower perfectly spicy and balanced, and the coppa salumi was very tasty.  The calabrese was a little heavy handed but very good, and the Brocolli/Salsicia wasn't amazing to be honest - dull flavors and slightly undercooked.  loved the Calabria chili oil at the table!  Great ambiance, very busy.  Wait staff and hosts were impersonal and seemed most focused on turning tables quickly.
author: Ben K.

description: FAVORITE RESTAURANT OF ALL TIME! I found this restaurant on Yelp about a year ago and have been going about every 3 weeks since then. The Diavola and Margarita pizzas are my favorites. Alex, Rad, and Benny are the best! Can't wait to go back in a few weeks!
author: Sandrine G.

description:
Il Casaro is a cheese lover's dream.

They've got several different kinds of cheese--buffalo, mozzarella, burrata, to name a few. But they've also got great pizza and amazing appetizers. 

We ordered the carpaccio salmon which was delicious with the squeezed lime slices that they provide. The calamari skewers are also fresh and tasty. We got a couple of pizzas and they were amazing too. The crust was soft but had that crispy charred part on the crust, and the sauce was flavorful. They also have a number of great desserts, including soft serve ice cream! I was definitely impressed by that, as I've found it hard to find soft serve, especially at restaurants and not dedicated dessert shops.

This place is a bit pricy, but I think it's probably worth it. We thought the service was great and the food came really quickly. Also, I liked that the portion sizes were just right and not so gigantic that you didn't have room for dessert ;D
author: Claire C.

description:
LOVE THIS PLACE! 

The pizza here is SO FRESH and they don't skimp out on the ingredients - you truly get a lot of cheese, arugula, and prosciutto if you order the prosciutto pizza! 

The ambiance here is also nice - you can watch them prepare and cook the pizzas in the fire oven from the open bar seating. 

Can't wait to come back to try the lasagna!
author: Hanna S.

description:
Rounding a 4.5-star review up to 5. This might not be the bestest, most spectacular Italian fare ever, but it's still really good. Best of all, in an increasingly expensive and inaccessible West Bay, prices are quite reasonable and the atmosphere and service quite welcoming and casual. 

Although the menu is fairly compact, sometimes simpler is better. Even then, the menu covers a good range of items, all of them satisfying and super delish. Apps like the polpette al sugo (ground beef meatballs with napoletana tomato sauce), the saffron risotto and mozzarella-stuffed arancini, or the nduja-stuffed potato croquettes are all very solid and could form a tapas-like meal. 

The pizza, meanwhile, was slightly less superlative. It's thin crust all right, but unless you use a fork and knife, it'll fall apart if you try to grab it with your hands. Nevertheless, you can't go wrong with the diavola or the prosciutto, and you can see everything being made before your eyes in the open preparation area and brick oven. 

Service is on point, and despite the compact nature of the space, there's a reasonable amount of seats for parties large and small. Thanks Yelpers for a great find that rises above all the tired, touristy old-school establishments in this area!
author: Vincent L.

description:
Came here after a weekend in New York because I clearly didn't get enough pizza there. Well, mostly, I just rediscovered my love for amazing thin crust proper Italian pizza and was on the search for some in SF.

I was so pleasantly surprised by Il casaro's pizza. It tasted like it could rival some of the better establishments in NYC!! 

We ordered (for 2 people) the Margherita and the Il Casaro pizzas, as well as the "imported burrata" and wood fired asparagus. Quite a lot of food but we were ok with getting some to go. I loved the margherita, I thought it was perfect tomato to cheese to crust ratio. Burrata was also excellent. I was surprised they named the il Casaro pizza after their establishment because I felt like the flavors were just ok. My boyfriend really liked that one though. He said he could taste garlic coming through but it just wasn't quite there for me. Still a great pie though! 

It was also really chill atmosphere on a Friday evening, not too many people and not too loud. That's truly a miracle for a good place in SF. No line out the door?!! Fresh air coming through as well.

Will definitely be back!
author: Su Lin Y.

description:
I'm a picky eater I'll come back, food good service good. 

Apparently the above is not enough to post maybe this waste of words will do
author: Mario P.

description:
Ok, so I think it's fair to say that Il Casaro doesn't need my positive review of their pizza, with its delicately-burned crust and dollops of bufala dotted over a perfectly-seasoned red sauce. Nor do they need too much more commentary on the ever-bustling scene that is their restaurant almost every single night of the week, a mix of hungry tourists and families, alongside locals who know about a good thing or three.

What I'm focusing on is a guy named Francesco Covucci, one of the owners of Il Casaro, who simply put, lives and breathes customer service. My review actually starts with Caviar, which failed horribly in delivering pizza from here a month or so ago. I tried the usual measure to contact them but they were the opposite of caviar service, and in my opinion, give those fish eggs a bad name. On a whim, I emailed Il Casaro, mentioning my frustration. In minutes, Francesco wrote back with diplomacy and understanding, immediately calming me down. At the whim of a venture-backed delivery startup, my pizza was clearly at risk. Not in a forced way, Francesco said that if I'd consider it, to come in and sit down for a meal.

Weeks went by but finally last night, we did, and there he was, gracious without trying to be, but also making sure our dishes arrived and we were always attended to (this while he ran the front of the house). We didn't see much of him after that, but his presence was there until the very end, and you could tell that our waitress was prepped to win us back as customers.

As some of you know, I used to work at Yelp years ago, where I pushed the idea of humanity and connection between reviewers and small businesses. That ideal has faded from Yelp over the years (sad!) but it's good to see Francesco and his team realizing that, while food is why customers might initial go, it's the human touch that keeps bringing folks back. Which we intend to, time and time again. 

Thanks, Francesco, for renewing my faith in why I choose to go out and dine in this city.
author: Nish N.

description:
Have heard so so much about this joint so I knew I needed to check it and what a better time when you have your favorite visitor in town! We were put on the wait list but only had to wait about 3 minutes and quite luckily, we got the best table in the place. We started with rosé which the waitress recommended. Honestly, it was a little dark for me as I told her I prefer lighter colored rosés. BUT OH WELL. Still drank the whole glass. Shortly after we ordered the beet salad and a 3 cheese pizza with arugula added on top. They brought out the salad first (which was fine) but we thought they would come together. Beet salad was v good. The pizza was...subpar...mainly because it was slightly undercooked for my tastebuds. But also the fault lies partially on me for not asking for crispier/burnt crust (yes I'm one of those weirdos). Loved how they had chili flakes on the table for us spice addicts. 

Good dining experience and loved the minimal wait but we watched people wait for much longer after we were seated. I can bet you'll find other great pizza places in North Beach so don't be too bummed if Il Casaro doesn't make it into your dining plans, but definitely try to fit it in if you can!
author: Kara N.

description:
Came here earlier this week with my sister on the hunt for great pizza. Both of us being vegetarians, we were a bit hesitant since I know this place is famous for its prosciutto and cured meat pizzas, but decided to give it a try anyway, and am super glad we did!! 

Our server Osvaldo was also vegetarian and was super knowledgable and sweet in our decision making. It's always best getting food recommendations from someone who shares your same dietary restrictions and preferences :) 
We ordered the eggplant meatballs can't remember the exact name but super delicious. Along with a simple but very yummy cheesy Margarita pizza with added burata cheese. It's hard finding great tasting Neapolitan style pizza in San Francisco but this place definitely does the trick! Food was phenomenal, Service very friendly and Attentive. Score! IL Cassarro for the Win!
author: Brooke S.

description:
One of my favorite pizza places in San Francisco! The incredibly fresh ingredients mixed with the wood fire pizza oven makes this place stand out. The service was well above average, Alexandra was quick on her feet, polite and genuinely interested in making sure all her customers were leaving with smiles on their faces!
Will definitely come back!
author: Mark R.

description:
A relatively small but airy pizzeria with a warm and friendly ambiance. I sat at the bar counter opposite the pizza oven and observed how the oven master at work, cooked 4 pizzas at 63-65 sec each (timed him!) which is remarkable, pizzas come out perfect every time! He thinks the oven temp is around 700F.

My pizza was puffy at the edge and the cheese is perfectly cooked in the middle.  The dough / base is  slightly stretchy and has a good bite.  A sprinkle of dried chili and a splash of extra virgin olive oil compliment the pizza very well.

Service was friendly and Alex in particular was funny and great!

One VERY good pizzeria in SF.  Pizza lovers make a note!
author: Majeed F.

description:
Saw the great reviews on this place and had to hop in here. Grabbed two pizza's :

Margherita -Tomato sauce, fior di latte mozzarella, extra virgin olive oil, basil 

Quattro Formaggi Mozzarella, goat cheese, asiago, gorgonzola 

We both agreed that we definitely like the Margherita more than the Quattro Formaggi. 

While we thought the pizza was solid we think there are better options in the City/Bay Area for thin crust pizza hence the 3 star rating.  The speed they make the pizza's is impressive as other's have noted when your pizza is "up". However, this place does get busy and when I was there at least there was only one person making pizza's so if there is a back log of pizza's to be made you will be waiting for a lil bit so don't expect your pizza's to come out super quick. 

Vibe and interior was nice and the wait staff was cool.
author: Rod M.

description:
Stopped by with my family on a Saturday afternoon and there wasn't too much of a wait! 

We got a buratta and il casaro pizza.

The buratta came with an arugula salad with cherry tomatoes and some bread (seemingly made of the same flour as the pizza dough)-- could basically be a small meal in and of itself. The buratta was creamy and nice. They added some olive oil and pepper to the arugula, which was perfect. The bread was chewy and a good complement to the buratta. 3.75/5.

The il casaro pizza came with mushroom and proscuitto.  Filling enough for 3 (albeit smaller sized) people. The oven is smack dab in the middle of the restaurant and the open kitchen makes it entertaining to watch the cooks prepare the food right in front of you if you sit at the center bar!
--

It's national pizza day so we came back! Chewy (but not hard to pull apart) crust, which felt more like a very delicious breadstick. Compared to other spots, the crust has a little more charred taste to it (not in a bad way though). Super thin crust. The broccoli and sausage pizza reminded me of the weird pizza combos we had at school. The cheese didn't stand out to me like it did at Little Star, but it was still good.
author: Nicole H.

description: My friend Simon took me here once in North Beach. I have come back 2 or 3 times. I came back yesterday with date. I wanted to eat at Italian Homemade, but it was too packed and there was nowhere to sit. So I said we should take the walk to Il Casaro for some pizza. I decided to get us the calzone pizza(around $17-18). We got the beet salad. It's yellow beets. It was all delightful. I had a Mexican coke and he had a Pellegrino lemon soda. There was just enough seating to fit us around 8pm. We went to Bimbo's after for a wonderful North Beach outing. Il Casaro has been dependable and delightful! Service is always good.
author: Denise C.

description:
Probably the best pizza I've had in San Francisco. 

Stumbled upon this place after a euphoric World Cup celebration at Kells (let's go COLOMBIA!) and needed some food. Walked into Il Casaro and got seated immediately (Sunday early afternoon). The space is super nice and open and we got a window table. 

We ordered the diavola pizza and burrata starter to share. The pizza was so delicious and the type of crust I love - super thin, charred, and chewy. They also have all the essentials ready to go on the table - crushed red pepper, calabrian chilli oil, and a bowl of calabrian chillis! Clear sign its a legit place.

Service was awesome as well! 

Can't wait to come back!
author: Laura D.

description:
An Italian friend and family have mentioned this is the best pizza they have had in America hands down so thats probably saying something.

It's a cute place to grab a few pizzas and wine. Loud and lively, a little chaotic, but still homey and comfortable. This is such a gem and can't wait to come back.

I had the Il Casaro pizza with the addition of burrata and it was absolutely delicious. Burrata really takes it to the next level

Atmosphere: 4/5
Food: 5/5
Service: 5/5
Overall Experience: 5/5
author: Elizabeth L.

description:
What's not to like about Il Casaro? Even though it's busy, wait times are short; portions are generous; the pizza is delicious; and prices are very reasonable!

Came here with a friend last weekend and had a great experience. They don't take reservations but will tell you how the line is looking if you call ahead. We were seated within 10 minutes of arrival. 

For our food, we shared an order of olives (which were large and flavorful, and a huge portion for $5!); an order of burrata (also a huge portion and tasty, served with flat bread that was a similar consistency to the pizza dough); and a Norma pizza. We loved everything, although the eggplant on the Norma wasn't really doing much to enhance the flavor of the slice. The crust had the perfect amount of bite and chewiness, and the cheese and sauce were flavorful and nice complements to each other. This was some of the best Neopolitan style pizza I've had in SF! Pizzas are 12" and we felt like this was plenty of food for two people, so we opted to share one instead of get two, and definitely didn't need a second. 

We also shared a bottle of house red (that day it was nero d'avola) for just $30! With tip, we each paid less than $40 for what felt like a feast. The ambience is nice: a casual bistro type setting with regular height and high top tables, centered around the brick oven. There's plenty of bar seating too.
author: Christine G.

description:
Very good pizza! I have been really disappointed about some Italian restaurant in this area and it feels good to find a spot like this one. The crust and the cheese are incredible, probably coming directly from Italy!!
Warning, it is pretty loud and i guess they could progress in serving timing, 2 out of 5 pizza have been served, then the remaining 3 waiting more than 5 minutes. It is a detail, but I am sure they can do better.
author: Leo A.

description:
I LOVE pizza and this is definitely one of my favorite pizza spots. I regret not coming sooner!!! I came here around 6:15pm on Wednesday with a friend and there was a good amount of people inside and we didn't have to wait. 

We ordered the Diavola pizza and burrata as our appetizer. Both of them were soooooo delicious! The burrata was milky and smooth. It came with a side of arugula salad with tomatoes and bread (like pizza dough). The Diavola pizza had good amount of spicy sausage on it. They don't skimp on the toppings which is awesome. Crust was good and had a bite to it. The cheese and tomato sauce on it was very good quality. I can eat this like everyday....... 

Service was very good. Not a big restaurant so the wait for this place might be a bit long if it was busy. 

I can't wait to come back!!
author: Joyce S.

description:
My neighborhood favorite! I was worried after I made the move from NYC that I wasn't going to be able to find good pizza in SF. The Pizza Gods were in my favor because I currently live 2 blocks away from this gem. My boyfriend stumbled upon this place on his way back from work and liked the brick oven so we decided to give it a go - best decision ever made. 

Everything you order is delicious. I haven't had a bad meal here. Their burrata and buffalo mozzarella is divine. The pizzas ... thin crust deliciousness. 

Highly recommend it! The place is always buzzing :)
author: Inci A.

description:
REALLY liked the food here, the service was a bit lackluster.

We got here around 5:30pm on a Thursday of a holiday week (the week after Xmas and before New Year's)

We got right in and got a great table right by the window.

The photos on Yelp and included a photo of some mortadella & mozzarella that looked great and we were set to order it, but did not see it on the menu (or the fried mozzarella), so wondering if this place changes its menu pretty often??

The cheapest bottle of red wine was $30. so we got that. we also ordered the burrata cheese which comes with flat bread (plain pizza dough really) and some arugula and tomatoes.

Each of the 3 of us ordered a lasagna (which apparently is only avail until it is sold out - so says the menu). They are all in the $15 range

I got the butternut squash one with came with chunks of pork sausage and mushrooms.  (you don't often see butternut squash lasagna WITH meat, so I was psyched.)

My other friend got the bolognese version, and my non-meat friend got the cheese lasagna which was my 2nd favorite - SUPER rich and full of cheese, even some blue cheese.  The size of the lasagna was a good portion, but NOT huge like is often the case (sad about no leftovers though)

The bill was about $80. 

I want to come back here - maybe try the pizza too.
author: Amy W.

description:
One of the best thin crust pizzas I have ever had ...PERIOD!!! (Got a Norma Pizza)
Also had Buratta for the first time ...loved it
author: Prateek R.

description: The ambiance was fun but that was the only thing I enjoyed.  The lady host seemed to be annoyed with us from the moment we walked in (we were there early before any table was occupied) and we asked to sit by the window.  We had three pizzas and all of them were average at best.  There were 5 of us and no one at our table gave the pizza a thumbs up.  I was very shocked because this place has a high rating.  Oh well.
author: R R.

description: No Words other than MMMMMM!!!   The Best Pizza in The City!!!!    Half the Diablo's and Prosciutto...  When in The City it will be my regular pizza stop!!
author: Leticia Z.

description: Love this place! It has great authentic Napolitain pizza - thin crust (although soggy sometimes), flavorful marinara sauce, and a great diversity of toppings. I really really love cheese so my go-to is the Burrata as appetizer and the quatro fromaggi pizza or the Il Casaro special (prosciutto, mushrooms, mozarella, and i add parmesan)
author: Rim K.

description:
Really good mozzarella! I really like the atmosphere and the set up. The buffala and prosciutto pizza were really good. However!!! The morzarella pizza at Tony's is better sorry guys! 

Tony's pizza is addicting. This one is good but not addicting ;)
author: Why-Tie Z.

description: I love the pizza at Il Casaro.  I also love how they are open a little later than other places.  The place can get a little too loud with the music and depending on how busy it is, so if you're trying to carry on a conversation with someone....say cause you're on a first date or something, it might not be the best place to go.  Other than that, I think this place is great!
author: Lan T.

description: Found this spot on Yelp a little over a year ago and now I eat here at least 2 times a month. The Burrata with Spicy Coppa is my favorite starter that comes with bread, arugula, and tomatoes. The Prosciutto and Diavola are my top 2 pizzas and I would bathe in their spicy chili oil if I could. Rad is the best waiter and he really takes care of his customers. Well worth the wait on a Friday night and great for any occasion!
author: Danielle K.

description:
After seeing such positive reviews for Il Casaro, my husband and I stopped in here to get some pizza one night while we were in the area. We ordered a margarita and the marinara pizza which was made right in front of us while we sat in the bar.  What was amazing to us is that the the pizzas literally only cooked for about 30 seconds in the oven. The pizzas were meh overall. They looked amazing but the taste and flavor wasn't really there. The sauce wasn't amazing but the cheese on the margarita was good. The service was also just fine, nothing amazing, just fine.

Overall, Il Casaro was just alright and we probably would try somewhere new before we would come back here again.
author: Ashley F.

description: LOVE love love. Pizza is super good! We ordered the cauliflower appetizer which was pretty oily for my taste. The pizza however was phenomenal!
author: Kayla M.

description:
Oh, hello buffalo mozzarella. Honestly, that's all the reason you need there for a visit. (Unless you're vegan.) And that was the primary goal--my friend made it clear that once we'd sunk a few easy ales at Vesuvio, stopping off here for cheese and wine was the only sensible option. So glad we did!

If you're into that Med style cuisine, you'll be well at home here. Cured meats, chilli oils, fresh rocket leaves, and great pizza await you. ("Arugula" for the non-British.) Our server was speedy, friendly, and attentive too.

The vibe is bright and airy, a little loud, and for sure a wee bit touristy. I don't mind, especially since we got seated so quickly. The house wine is also perfectly fine if you don't want to spend a bunch more. Mostly, I loved feeling like I was on holiday and that we were stuffed on three small plates and one pizza between four. Go get some!
author: Rowena H.

description:
Stopped there for a snack on a lazy Sunday afternoon (and also because Caffè Macaroni was closed...). Great find, great surprise!

We only had some appetizers: pizza bread, spicy coppa, fresh mozarella (served with arugula salad) and roasted cauliflower.
The cauliflower was my favorite, perfectly cooked, tender, slightly brown, tossed in a delicious oily caper garlicky sauce. Wood oven baked. 5 stars.
The mozzarella was nice but definitely not the best I had. "OK" I'd say. Spicy coppa was good, I'm wondering where / which brand they import for.
The pizza bread was excellent, I was able to "build" perfect bites with arugula cheese and coppa. Loved it.

Quality products are used here. The pizza dough is probably the best I had in USA.
Very professional service.Staff gives good advice. I'll go back and try their pizza soon.

Cons: the music, doesn't fit the style of the restaurant and makes the place too loud.
author: Sylvain B.

description:
Il Casaro is a kind of unassuming joint in a kind of touristy part of town, but the food's a winner. The inside is airy and relaxed, and the service is absurdly speedy. In fact, everything about Il Casaro felt like it was fast-forwarded -- when my party of four rolled up to the waitlist the server told us to wait "1 to 4 minutes", which seems REALLY specific. It's probably a pretty high-traffic world and turning tables of tourists as rapidly as possible is the name of the game. 

Maybe a little TOO airy--we were seated as far from the door on a fairly temperate evening and it was crazy cold. Then again, with the door closed the pizza oven might heat the place up way too fast. 

Speaking of the oven, the food was real fast--just like the wait and the service. I assume the oven is heated to like a zillion degrees and the pizzas are in there for half a minute. Which is fine by me, because the food's great. It's hard to find solid pizza in town and Casaro's is more than acceptable. Definitely get something, anything, with buffalo mozzarella on it. 

Great place for a quick (keyword: quick!) meal. I went on a Monday night; it might be a nightmare to get a seat on a Friday or Saturday, but that says more about the neighborhood than Casaro itself.
author: Jim M.

description:
Amazing Italian restaurant in Chinatown! 
We got a plate of prosciutto, and a Calzone pizza to share. We were surprisingly amazed by the taste of the pizza, far away from greasy, and perfectly cook. The atmosphere is cool, even it's noisy. Love the fact that we were seating at the bar and could watch the preparation of the pizza. Great experience, I'll be back for sure
author: Lauu H.

description:
!Mouthwatering pizza!

Everything is fresh and tasty. Pizza, green olives, salami, mozzarella, and desserts are simply good.

Taste: Fabulous!
Price: Average. I wish they had happy hour.
Customer service: Great.
Parking: Street.
Location: Close to the famous cannoli shop.
author: Keiko M.

description:
Pillowy pizza crust with a doughy consistency paired with creamy mozzarella and fresh tomato sauce was a dream come true. I could elaborate, but it really boils down to this.

Turn down the volume in the restaurant and you've got yourselves 5 stars.
author: Cici T.

description:
Did a little research and discovered there is a little italy area in San Francisco. After burning off calories exploring the area we decided to look for an Italian place to eat.  We turned to trusty Yelp. 

We got here about 6:15pm on a Friday. As with most places in the city that we have seen it is not very large in size but they use the space well. There are probably seats for 40 to 50 people including the counter area around where they prepare the food.

We reviewed the menu and placed our orders. We ordered the Polpette Al Sugo (ground beef meatballs with napoletan tomato sauce) appetizer, a Diavola pizza (tomato sauce, mozzarella, Italian salami and calabrian peppers on the side) and a calzone (tomato sauce, mozzarella, ham, mushroom, arugula, raspa dura cheese). 

The Polpette Al Sugo was an amazing start, very tasty. The main courses were also fabulous. The pizza had just a little bite.

Within 45 minutes of our arrival, there was a line outside.

Overall a great experience. The only negative I can think of is that it was a little noisy inside.
author: Mike B.

description:
Pizza is my jam and Il Casaro serves up a pretty hot dish. 

The ambience here is pretty hip and loud, and would be a great and fun setting for a small group of friends. Although, if you have more than 4 people there's a good chance you won't be able to hear or make conversation with anyone but the person right next to you until you're both into yelling- which after a few drinks is actually totally fine, turns out. 

The service was on point and we had no problem digging into the menu. The cauliflower was definitely my favorite item. I'd go back for that alone but next time I won't be sharing. The olives were as to be expected and same for the shishito peppers. The arancini was good, filling, and piping hot but even after all that I somehow found myself regretting not getting the corn since they did the cauliflower so well and I would've loved to have drizzled some of their fantastic Calabrian chili oil on it. Just another reason to come back, I guess. 

The pizzas are around 10" but if you're a crust-hater like me it's worth noting that a significant number of those inches are taken up by toppingless crust. I'm just not a bread person and never have been so I'm usually always the person who has the plate full of crusty pizza ends at the end of the night and that was definitely the case here. I ate the center of the pizza and really enjoyed it, but when I lined up all the crust at the end it ended up being just shy of half the pizza. Personally, if I'm getting a pizza, I want the topping to go all the way to the edge of the crust... otherwise why not just order bread? 

I did LOVE their few but delicious add on topping options like a farm egg, the saltiest olives ever, mushrooms, and Calabrian chilies which are basically my favorite things for a pizza. 

For dessert I ordered myself a Nutella and banana pizza and less one slice, I ate the whole thing. And let the record show that with the dessert pizza they actually spread the toppings further so there's less crust. Yay! 

The pizzas were also priced really well with my base margarita being just $12. That's a price tag I'll definitely come back for as I have a friend who I know would absolutely love this 'za.
author: Candice G.

description:
I have to admit, I was surprised to find such a great pizza joint in North Beach. If you're a Bay Area native, you know that this neighborhood (aka "Little Italy") is mostly home to cheesy tourist spots. But I'm happy to report that this Neapolitan pizzeria is legit.

I had the Diavola pizza (tomato sauce, mozzarella, Italian salami, Calabrian peppers served on a thin, chewy crust). With each bite, my taste buds were shouting "Mamma mia!"
It's actually quite a large pizza for one person, especially if you have an appetizer or two beforehand. I'd recommend sharing your pie with a friend. I could only eat half of mine, and wound up doggy-bagging the rest for lunch the next day. Though truth be told, by the time I got home, I couldn't help but dive back in to the leftovers. Yes, the pizza is that good.

If pizza ain't your jam, Il Casaro has other tasty offerings. I highly recommend the Polpette al Sugo (meatballs with tangy tomato sauce); the Cavolfiori (Roasted cauliflower, capers, garlic, calabrian chili oil); and the Arancini (fried rice balls with melted cheese in the middle). Everything was de-lish!

Service was friendly and fast. Keep in mind, this place gets crowded and loud. I wouldn't necessarily recommend this spot for an intimate date. And if you go with a group of 4 or more people, you'll have to shout to hear one another.

My only gripe is that they don't take reservations. So if you come here, be prepared to wait. But believe me, this pizza is well worth it!
author: Kevin B.

description:
Wow, wow, wow. I came here with some coworkers for dinner and it was absolutely incredible! The dishes were exploding with flavor and I truly experienced a taste of Italy in every bite. Though busy on the regular, i'm sure. It has great vibes and an amazing window that makes it open-air. 

For apps, we ordered their cauliflower, olives, MEATBALLS {must!!}, and shishito peppers. Everything was so fresh and it was evident that they used fine ingredients and love in all of their dishes. The meatballs definitely stood out as some of the best that i've had. They had SO much flavor. 

For my pizza, I ordered the Il Casaro because DUH, it is named after the restaurant which i'm assuming means that it is probably a fan favorite. It was cooked to perfection with a chewy crust, fresh cheeses, prosciutto, and mushrooms. I would 100% recommend it, the thought still makes my mouth water.

To finish, we got the Nutella and banana pizza because why not?! We were already carb-loading so another few pieces of doughy perfection won't do any more harm than has already been done. Anywho, if you're in the city and looking for 5-star, authentic pizza, Il Casaro will not disappoint!
author: Hailey P.

description:
A happening spot, and kinda cool to sit at the counter and watch these guys churn out pizzas like they could do it in their sleep. There was a long waitlist, but we got seated almost immediately, and the place is cozy packed with people. 

That said, I loved the the olives and roasted asparagus appetizers we got more than my pizza itself. I ordered the Norma, and it was just okay. However, the Tiramisu (which I scarfed down in excitement and didn't get a photo of) was one of the best I've ever had.
author: Avani G.

description:
Here is  a very good margherita !!! Great atmosphere! Friendly service. 
Food - 5 
Staff - 5
author: Georgiy R.

description:
I love this place! It's a block over from my office and we came here a few times for lunch meetings. 

They serve authentic pizza made to order and super quick in a brick oven right behind the counter (which you can also sit if you have a small party or are dining alone). I especially love the melon salad but last time I went it was not on the menu anymore.

The roasted cauliflower is my new favorite replacement appetizer. 

I love all the spicy pizzas as well as the Norma which has eggplant and mushrooms on it. They also added a pasta sections recently but have no had a chance to try it. I will be back to though.
author: Jazmine S.

description: Best pizza in the city - love that they have thin crust + smaller pie size so you can order 2 and try a little bit of both. Can get crowded but waitlist should not take long.
author: Emily M.

description: The pizza was good, the reason I give 3 stars was because we received terrible service by our waiter. He was very shit faced, not friendly, and barely came by to check on us if we needed more water, refills, napkins, nothing. To be fair, the restaurant was busy and packed and it seemed he was the only waiter that night but considering he was the only one available, his face gave the expression he did not want to be there so that kind of made our first time visit not that enjoyable but the pizza was good, not great, just good. I did enjoy the neighborhood and walking around seeing the various Italian spots though!
author: Marcela O.

description:
Looking for some amazing pizza in North Beach without too much of a fuss but not by the slice place either? Oh That also happens to play poppin music and has quick service? Wellllll This is your place!

We went on a Friday night and were told a 30 min wait for 3 but really ended up waiting less than 20, and we ordered a bottle of wine outside while we waited!

We ordered the burrata and an eggplant with tomato sauce dish as starters. The burrata was terrific , the eggplant came in a mushy ball with tomato sauce with was good but prob wouldn't get it again. We also got the Bufilina and Margherita , both were some of the best pizza ive had in SF although the Buflina was def my fav! Ended off with the tiramisu which was so good!!

It was so quick , we were in and out within an hour! So a good option if you dont have a ton of time. In my opinion it is comparable to Tony's (yes yes I know, Tony's is the best)
author: Hetal P.

description:
As an avid believer in the yelp community I always follow the reviews to new and exciting adventures.  This time it did not work out, I was honestly so let down.  We came to il Casaro hoping to taste the authenticity and craft in their pizzas.  What ended up happening was poor customer service and poor pizza.  I'm not quite sure how they manage to make a pizza that is both soggy, yet completely burnt.  With a Margherita pizza there aren't many toppings to cover up a bland sauce so it is important that time is taken to make sure that the couple ingredients that are used, are used well.  Unfortunately they missed the mark here; it was not something I would ever come back for.  I will however come back for the burrata appetizer plate, though I would advise the restaurant to serve it with more than three tiny pieces of pizza dough, it was amazing! The cheese was so fresh and light and the arugula added just the perfect amount of zing.  Overall, I was not impressed.  For their prices they really need to up their quality. 

To new adventures, 
Paulina Ceja
author: Paulina C.

description: Showed up 40 minutes before closing and was denied a seat.  I guess closing at midnight means closing at 11? Felt pretty bad, don't feel good.
author: Cordell B.

description:
We only had appetizers here but will be back for some kickass looking (and smelling) pizza, I'm sure! Il Casaro was part of our "tour" of little Italy in north beach so we decided to make this place our first stop, since it boasted being a mozzarella bar as well as a pizzeria. While I was disappointed to find out they only serve mozzarella and burrata but no special variations on either (served simply with arugula, tomatoes, and crusty pizza dough triangles), I was very happy with the quality of the burrata. It was delicious and I could have eaten 3 more servings, easily. We also got the roasted calamari and zucchini which was PERFECTLY cooked. 

My only critiques for both dishes - a touch of salt would have gone a long way on the calamari and an herb infused olive oil as an accoutrement for the pizza dough triangles - but maybe I'm being picky because other people were just slathering the burrata straight on the triangles. I was just happy eating it straight off the plate, lol.

The place is small and packed - we got lucky that we were only two people and got seated at the pizza bar right away. We loved the show! I would probably refrain from bringing a large group, you'll be really cramped.
author: Rachel A.

description: Awesomeness.  Small place but they get to you right away.... the staff work really well with one another and makes things churn right along. Great pizza (margarite) Also enjoyed a side of eggplant meatball- I enjoyed but friend didn't care for the mushier consistency.
author: Su B.

description:
Second time here, first time i was here i rated 5 stars. 
Service was medium not with any attention to us the guests.
Borata chesse good as last time only this time we got it with a cold bread on the side. When we asked why it is not hot we got the answer that we came a long time after they took it out from the oven.
Pizza was tasty and wine was good.
Restaurant was very noisy.
Over all experience 3 stars. Pretty disappointing.
We will probably check other restaurants next time.
author: Tali R.

description:
This friend of mine used to live in Milan, Italy.  She has been on a quest for the most authentic Italian Pizza she could find.  She did her own research and found this place may just be the spot to satiate her Italian cravings.

Im game for any new place, as you can tell.  We had a reservation but there was still a little bit of a wait.  We stood outside and the servers come out and ask you if you want Prosecco.  Are you kidding me?  Yes, I always want Prosecco, in a real champagne glass even.  You had me at Prosecco, I swear.

We started with the Wild Boar Salamino.  This is my new favorite thing.  If you've never had it, go and get it immediately!  Its amazing on every level.

My friend got her Pizza Margherita.  All of their pizza's are wood fire grilled right there in front of you.  The place does get rather hot, even on a cold night in San Francisco. You will not need a coat inside.  

I had the Spaghetti Carbonara.  It was so buttery and rich.  The pancetta was cut so small and melted in your mouth.  It had just enough pepper to give it a little kick.  I was told that my dish was a very typical real Italian Carbonara.  I had zero complaints.

Service was excellent.  It helped my dinning partner speaks fluent Italian with the servers who are also, really Italian.  

If this is the most authentic Italian you can get out of Italy, Im convinced.
author: Ivy R.

description:
The crust here has that authentic Neapolitan char. We had one plain Margherita and one Margherita with sausage. My husband and I agreed that the plain one was better--although if you are a fan of sausage on your pizza, they add a generous amount. It's good Neapolitan pizza, but in born-in-Italy Hubby's opinion, Tony's pizza just up the road is a little better.

The best thing we had here was the oven-baked calamari and zucchini skewers appetizer. It was well-seasoned and served on a bed of arugula. Great starter. House red wine was fine.

Atmosphere includes a TV playing soccer, some loud music, and good looking young Italian (male) waitstaff.
author: Patti I.

description:
margherita pizza : it is like diving into a bed made from 5000 lbs of mozzarella pillows. soft chewy thin, mellow, melting perfection! 

quattro formaggi: sophisticated, flavorful, quite a bit going on here. 

loved the chilli oil/chilli pickle accompaniments. 

quick service. get here on a sunday evening 5/6 pm, no wait, no rush. chill at the bar. 

I did not enjoy the burrata much. Maybe I'll try again next time. aaaaaah! i will be driving all the way from the bay for this pizza, again, most definitely. don't hesitate to be at il casaro.
author: Raj R.

description:
Just one word to describe their pizza:
                     A M A Z I N G!!!!
It brought me back to the time I have spent in Italy, in particular when I lived in Naples!
The dough is fluffy, airy, soft with a nice bubbled crust, exactly how it is must be (in order to be qualified as a Neapolitan pizza). I enjoyed a margherita with extra burrata, fresh and delicious. Service was fast and efficient.
Prices are average considering the area, parking can be a bit challenging, but definitely it's worth the wait!
author: Michelle C.

description:
I took a Margherita, it was good but not the best I've eaten. The mozzarella was a bit rubbery, but the dough was really good! My husband took a Prosciutto and I found it much better!
I come from a place close to Italy, so I am used to eat very good pizzas. As an almost-Italian person, I would recommend this pizzeria!
author: Caroline G.

description:
Who ever gives this place less than perfect score they better just not go there. 

Take it from the biggest food snob. 

This IS IT!!  BY FAR BEST AUTHENTIC NAPOLEON PIZZA in Northern California and one of the best in the world period.
author: Sean A.

description: Best pizza in the city!! Great service, great atmosphere, ​and the food... amazing!
author: Luciana B.

description:
First time visiting this restaurant and the food was so good. Worth a visit while in the City as a local or a tourist. Attentive service and great recommendations by our server. I can't make wood fired pizza at home so this was a treat for sure. 
I loved it and hope to go there again soon.
author: N L.

description:
Don't mind me while I'm just throwing my 5 star review on the pile with all the others. If you want delicious, authentic Italian pizza, come here!  That's all there is to say really.  
Alright fine, I'll describe the pizza: The crust is nice and thin but not dry. Cheese and sauce have a great flavor. The pizzas are  baked in a wood fired oven, where the stay for only 90 seconds. Yeah I did time it, so what?
Service is friendly, fast, and attentive. The interior is clean, modern, and casual and there are TVs showing soccer. They also have typical Italian drinks. I'll be back! Many times.
author: Steven M.

description:
Mamma Mia if you want good pizza, this is the place for you!  This is hands down the pizza in SF (sorry Tony).  I have now eaten here twice; the first time i ate here I ordered delivery and the second time was in the restaurant. 

I will say that this pizza is best right out of the pizza oven.  I live in SoMa and by the time the pizza arrived, the dough was soggy (but still so delicious).  This pizza, as all pizza, is best hot or cold.  Lukewarm pizza is not the best.

In person, hot out of the oven, this is the best pizza I have ever had. Ever.  EVER.  The Il Diavolo and Il Casaro are both incredible. You really can't go wrong with any of the choices.  I love the spicier meats, but I've had just the cheese and the mushrooms and both were great options as well.

If you like Napoletana pizza, this really is the best place to go.  The ingredients are all outstanding: the tomato sauce is the best I've ever had, the cheese is fantastic, and the char on the crust after coming out of the oven is perfect.  I will be coming back to Il Casaro for the rest of my life.
author: Nick D.

description:
Best pizza in the city, hands down. 

I've been a few times for work lunches but went most recently for dinner. We walked in and got seated within 5 minutes (at 8PM on New Years Eve no less!) as a party of 8. We ordered a few pizzas off the menu for the group - standouts were the Il Casaro and the Bufalina. I don't want to be one of *those* people who says things like "I lived in __ country and this is just as good as the __ there"...but seriously, this pizza is as good as any I had when I lived in Rome. Perfect crust, just chewy enough but still crisp, lots of cheese, minimal sauce. Wow. Everything about this place is awesome; food, staff, atmosphere. If you're in North Beach don't pass it up!
author: Kathryn P.

description: This place is simply the Best, every time we come back to San Francisco we make it a point to stop here. The staff and the food are excellent, quaint not great for big parties but the staff accommodated us as we had 11 family members. Can't wait to stop by again until next time thank you.
author: Rob T.

description: One of my favorite spots in San Francisco. It was one of the first restaurants that my fiancé and went to and the place where we got engaged. The whole staff went the extra mile to make everything special for us. This is our go-to spot for a wonderful dinner, social occasions, and our special moments.
author: Hannah L.

description:
Trending down. Used to be one of the best (and affordable) pizzas in SF. Prices went up and quality down. Menu changed and I'm missing some of my favorites like mozzarella in carrozza. 
Last time I visited with family (party of 5 - all Italians, mind you!) for evening pizza. Pizza was OK, but 2 pizzas came 5-6 minutes after the first 3. Service was rushed and unfriendly. Got seated at a table  next to the window on a cool evening and we had to keep jackets and hats on because they refused to close the window despite the super cold draft coming in. If you have ventilation issues find other solutions other than making your customers uncomfortable. Not sure I will go back anytime soon.
author: Emanuele O.

description: We found this great restaurant in North Beach. We ordered the margarita pizza and two glasses of wine. The pizza was really good, expect to pay $13-$20 for the pizza. The thing that I like about this place was that they had a mozzarella bar. It's a chill environment where you can watch the games playing, since they have multiple big screen TVs for customers to watch a game. If you are craving pizza, check this place out, highly recommended
author: Michelle D.

description: Went to Il Casaro during the Italian Heritage parade which, for most restaurants, means long waits, slow service, hiked prices and generally less pleasant experience. Friends really wanted to get Italian on this day, so we tried out Il Casaro and were very happy to find friendly, attentive service, reasonable wait times and food that was worth waiting for. We shared a pizza, two orders of burrata cause it's the best and some veggie sides (which were so-so). I love how this place doesn't put on any aires and doesn't feel touristy at all.
author: New2Northbeach N.

description: I'm so glad I found this spot. Went for and early lunch before our flight back to la. There wasn't much of a wait. The serves was good and the food was great wish I could give it more than 5 stars. The Pizza is to die for. Sooo good! Can't wait to go back to sf.
author: Rebecca E.

description:
We really wanted some good authentic pizza and this did not disappoint. Had prosciutto (highly recommend), meat pizza (can't remember name but w/ calabrian peppers it was very good), and mushroom prosciutto. 

Also had to try Nutella pizza for dessert which was good but smelled better than it tasted... still, you can't really go wrong with smothering chocolate hazelnut on warm bread. 

Casual, fast service with a couple TVs - great place for a lunch or casual dinner in North Beach.
author: Victoria B.

description:
Had dinner here last night and was a bit let down. It was Friday night and super busy, so I think quality control suffered. Both my wife and I ordered a pizzas, but both were under cooked. I know with this style of cooking pizza an extra 15 sec in the oven can make a big difference. I guess our pizzas were pulled put a bit to early and the dough was still raw. 
The service was great, the ingredients were great, but the execution was lacking. I have a feeling we just got unlucky, because this place seemed super popular. But that was our experiance. Did not live up to the hype.
author: Steven X.

description:
This place was really interesting during our 3rd visit to San Francisco.  Located in North Beach (Little Italy), it is right off the main road leading into the area on Columbus Ave.  We get there on a Friday night and had to wait for an open table because it was packed, but we didn't wait long though.  

Anywho, once we got seated, the service was great.  There was a bit of a language barrier there because I'm sure these guys were straight up Italian, like from the old country Italian, :)  because when we put in our order, I think something got lost in translation, because our first set of pizzas were all wrong.  I think we screwed them up because we ordered 2 pizzas, with half this and half that and add this and not that type of order and I think they aren't used to that, plus the dude didn't write any of it down either, sooooo.

Well needless to say, they didn't take it too well by us sending​ food back, but hey the pizzas were all wrong.  So this waiter gets insulted and complains to his manager, then comes back to our table and says that his manager will be taking over because apparently he can't get our order right.  So then she comes to our table and acts as if it was our fault or something and then started to take our order again, and again she didn't write it down either, so what the heck!?  And that's when the service declined.  We did get our pizzas how we ordered them, but with an attitude, LOL!!

Now to the food: The pizzas were great, as any neapolitan pizza would be and the pasta carbonara was decent.  You can tell the pasta was old school style, nothing fancy, but still good.  As a matter of fact, the whole place was old school, nothing fancy, just a cool little restaurant to have some good Italian food.  At any seat in the house you'll be able to hear and see that hustle and bustle of Columbus Ave.  I would recommend this place to anyone out there, just don't order a half this, half that pizza.  :)  I would have given them 5 Stars if it weren't for the attitude.
author: David S.

description:
My husband yelped this place....decided to go here in between times at the convention we were visiting. 

Greeted right away which was nice. They were friendly, personable, and seated us right away. Not too much longer, we had a server helping us. Customer service....yes, pretty good so far. 

We sat at the bar top, which was pretty cool because you get to see them make the pizzas, calzones, etc. Everything here is fresh and made to the order. 

We had the lasagna. Pretty damn good. Filling. Tasty. Delicious. 

We didn't get to try a lot of the food items . But a clean and nice environment, good food, beer on tap (no alcohol ), and standard city prices. I would definitely come back here....at least to try the pizza.
author: Grace G.

description: Disappointed. Used to be a favorite location. Not sure what happened on Wednesday evening - between the waiter literally coming back and asking us three times to verify our very uncomplicated order, the prosciutto pizza being severely undercooked, the wine being 'hot' - stored improperly, it was needless to say, underwhelming.
author: Sheryl F.

description:
Hot damn, this pizza is good!

Let's start by stating that I have a serious problem. On average, I eat pizza four times a week and mostly for dinner. It's an incredible habit that started long ago in New Haven, Connecticut but, I'm sure glad it started. 

In my book, Il Casaro is currently the reigning champ for best pizza in San Francisco. It's a perfect rendition of a classic neapolitan pizza and done with such precision that it makes my soul sing. Chewy, light crust that is perfectly burnt, San Marzano tomato sauce and beautiful mozzarella cheese make this pie unbeatable. 

I'll be back tomorrow. :)
author: Benjamin F.

description:
Really good pizza, the music is extremely loud and causes conversation to not be possible. Upon asking for the music to be lowered, the answer is always "the manager likes it that way". It's unfortunate.
Otherwise, 5 stars.
author: Paolo E.

description:
We found this restaurant through yelp. Solid high marks with a great location and we were seated immediately with no reservation. Tuesday in the summer around 7pm. 

We both had pizza which is absolutely the point. I had pizza with prosciutto and mushrooms and my wife had margherita pizza. Both were cooked perfectly and very good. 

Wait staff was attentive despite the crazy busy atmosphere. Patrons were pleasant and enjoying their evening. 

Good value for the money. Long line waiting as we left around 8.
author: Jeff S.

description: What a save for my drunk/tired friend/roommate!!!! We were out at happy hour on empty stomachs (one of those bars with good drinks but no food) and my friend is a real lightweight, and she suddenly turned to me saying "I'm hungry." I had inquired earlier about her boyfriend's whereabouts, but unfortunately he was not coming to our work happy hour so she was solely my responsibility. I quickly searched on Yelp for a nearby restaurant with food for takeout, and my eye caught Il Casaro. I browsed the photos and immediately knew that the prosciutto pizza was after my heart - it was a simple combination of marinara, arugula, and prosciutto, but simplicity is what the soul craves. I placed an order online and was relieved to walk past the crowd waiting to be seated outside, and was offered a bar seat and water while I watched my pizza getting baked and dressed. I walked out with my beauty less than 5 minutes later, and grabbed my friend to go home, where we demolished the pizza. Her drunken self found great satisfaction and relief from the pizza, and I found love.
author: Lily W.

description: Really nice service, people are kind and helpful and pizza there is heaven! My fav pizza place in SF !
author: Jana B.

description:
It was our last night in SF. We took the Alcatraz Night Tour and when it ended, almost at 10 p.m., we were hungry. We wanted Italian so we went back to Little Italy/North Beach.

Being that it was late on a Sunday night, options were few, but Il Casaro sounded like a neat spot to check out, so off we went.

There was one other group in the restaurant when we arrived. Seeing NoBe on a Sunday night gave us a totally different perspective than our Saturday afternoon, very touristy visit. Now, it felt far more local.

Our waiter was lovely and recommended a delightful Italian wine. We shared burrata (creamy mozzarella with bread) and olives. It was so yummy with the wine. We were right in front of the wood burning brick oven, so pizza was a must. I tried the lasagna and was not at all disappointed.

It was a perfect ending to a super fun vacation in the great city of San Fran!
author: Ekatarina V.

description:
Get the pizza and not the pasta. There's a reason why there's tons more pizza options on their menu and only a few pasta choices. I came with a group of 6 on a Saturday night and even though the restaurant was packed we were seated within 10 minutes. 

Truffle Burrata- this one is a MUST! The truffle burrata is AMAZING! Comes with a little bit of arugula and cherry tomatoes on the side. 

Il Casaro pizza- LOVED the cremini mushrooms on this pizza. It was a perfect balance of flavor between the mushrooms, the prosciutto, and the mozzarella and grana padana cheese. The crust is perfection! Probably one of the best pizzas I've had in the city. 

Canneloni pasta- don't get this. The portion is kind of small and it just wasn't good. Lacked the wow factor.
author: Mai Y.

description: My wife's Italian so by default we had to find the most Italian place in SF. The burrata was top notch. The pizza was made to perfection, there was no cheeping out on toppings. Plenty of prosciutto on the pizza, all the meat and cheese plates came with arugula. Server recommended an excellent wine and it was actually the cheapest on the menu. All and all top quality pizza, tastes like it came outta the pizza oven in the backyard. If you want to sit down for pizza you'd be crazy not to stop here!
author: Johnny B.

description:
I was down in another bar looking for a place to eat some good Italian food and get pizza. I was looking on yelp and found this place and we walked up to have the best lasagna and brick oven pizza in San Francisco.  My friends boyfriend ordered a bottle of red wine and they had a pizza and my girlfriend and I had the two different types of lasagna one Bolognese and the other was a butternut squash. 
The atmosphere was open and bright happy and very spacious. Server was polite kind funny and checked on us off and to make sure everything was good and if we needed anything. I also ordered a calzone need to go to take home and he put in an extra side of dipping sauce and everything and it was absolutely delicious. 
I would highly recommend this place for anyone who wants brick oven Pizza a really good Italian food and excellent service. I will return when I come back to San Francisco!
author: Gail H.

description:
Seriously the best pizza in San Francisco! Everything I've had here is amazing. The atmosphere is great and if you sit at the bar you can watch them make the pizza in the giant wood fire oven. Hopefully the tourists are at Tony's so you won't have to wait long, boy are they making the wrong choice!

I recently found out that I have a dairy allergy but I will gladly risk it for Il Casaro burrata!
author: Barie W.

description:
Sunday, a little after lunch time, between 1-2PM. You walk into this cute cafe/restaurant where the wide windows let in plenty of sunlight. It smells amazing, like fresh baked bread and melted cheeses. It's a little warmer, but comfortable temperature especially considering SF's cold weather.

My boyfriend and I sit down at a table for four near the window since there's not many other options. We're offered sparking and tap water.

We split the sotto mar pizza (the one with clams and squid). We're surprised that a) the clams are still in their shells and b) there's no cheese on the pizza. We de-shell the clams and each start on a slice. DELICIOUS. We're a bit too American and feel weird that the pizza doesn't have cheese on it so we ask for some. The servers happily oblige and bring fresh grated cheese (very finely grated, like snow texture) in a small bowl to us.

We sprinkle the cheese on top and continue eating our amazing pizza. Splitting one pizza between the two of us was just the right amount for us both to feel satisfied/full but not overly so.

The experience was a bit dreamlike. Definitely recommend coming back! Food and ambiance were perfect for a Sunday afternoon with the boyfriend.

Plus it's right by City Lights, so great to make a date of pizza + books.
author: Mimi T.

description:
II Casaro was one of 3 places recommended by a local coworker to get Italian in the North Beach area. I looked at all three and this one had me sold on the mozzarella bar part of it. I LOVE fresh mozzarella. 

I went with another coworker and we got the castelvetrano olives and burrata mozzarella to start and they were delicious. The olives were normal olives (nothing special, olives are olives) but the burrata mozzarella was gooey and creamy and delicious.

Since my coworker didn't eat meat, we got the Quattro Formaggi pizza, which is four cheese pizza which was also delicious. I remember leaving the restaurant realizing I just ate basically bread and cheese for dinner. Can't complain there!

Their wine list seems to have a good selection - I got the prosecco and it was good, though I haven't had many bad proseccos.

I feel bad I can't remember my server's name, but he was engaging and knowledgeable and helped us choose which mozzarella to get. Service was quick and it wasn't very full when we got there around 6 p.m. but when we left, there were people waiting outside.
author: Amber B.

description:
This place is truly a 3-star restaurant, but I had to bump it to 4 purely for the pizza. Seriously, if you're thinking about ordering anything aside from the burrata or pizza, don't. Unless it's wine. They have a great wine list, and wine is delicious. 

Il Casaro is amore a prima vista. It's an intimate restaurant with windows that open onto the sidewalk for an al fresco feel. There are Italian servers and patrons filling the air with thick accents and clinks of wine glasses. The smell of the wood fired oven lingers like a sweet perfume.

The first time we came for dinner in a group of 4. We ordered the arancini, burrata, the tagliatelle carbonara, and the prosciutto pizza to share family style. The burrata was really good. Sadly the carbonara was pretty bland and disappointing and felt like a waste of a dish. Our arancini came out at the same time as our pizza, and was barely warm, so I think they had forgotten about it. The pizza was outstanding and flew off the pan - it was the only thing we really liked about the meal. Service was a little slow, but it was a weekend night so it was to be expected.

On our second trip, we had a group of 3 for lunch. Wiser after our first visit, we each ordered a different pizza. We tried the diavola (which was outstanding), a margherita, and the prosciutto again. The pizzas were all fantastic, with the diavola standing out as the clear favorite. 

The main issue with this visit was the service. There was just one server, and the poor girl looked like she might have a breakdown at any moment. Although it wasn't crazy busy, it was evident that she was scrambling between tables and trying to keep up. She took our order by writing on her hand because she had lost her paper and we went without drinks for most of our meal. I felt bad for her, but it was not a good dining experience. 

I think if they hired more help, it would make a huge improvement to not just the service, but getting the food out hot and fresh. Still, I'd come back anytime for their pizza. A little pricey, but absolutely worth it!
author: Kate K.

description: I have been here for 5 times and the experience has been OK until today. They forgot my pizza. I understand it's busy, but if you welcome more ppl than you actually can serve and take care, it's a problem I guess.
author: Zeynep D.

description:
Not to be totally negative but I feel very compelled to leave this review after my friends and I eagerly drove to get what looked like the best Pizza in SF according to yelp. Well; soggy pizza is not appetizing or in any way authentic, neither is inferior quality ingredients. This is NOTHING like pizza in Italy or even New York/New Jersey/ Philadelphia. My photo speaks for itself.

I got a margarita and my friend got the prosciutto. Both were undercooked and his toppings without flavor. Procuttto had that stale-old texture and no cured flavor. Shaved (Pecorino?) was also without any of the lovely tyrosine (this salty crystals in great cheese). My margarita had just two basil leafs on the whole pie :(

When the pizza came to the table it did look great; exactly like the Yelp photos... but the finished product was so underwhelming in taste and texture! Being an east-coaster I've lived a life with good pizza. Save yourself the huge disappointment: go to Pizzetta 211 or Beretta. 

*Service was very good, atmosphere fun and clean, plus the staff was friendly so I'll leave a 2 rather than 1*
author: Steve B.

description:
Be very careful with this restaurant, they take more money from your credit card than they should!

I did tip them 18% but they did charge me 22% instead, when I claimed back a day later, they said that they had no copy of the receipt
author: Jordi P.

description:
Il Casaro Pizzeria & Mozzarella Bar, at 348 Columbus Ave. in San Francisco's storied North Beach, is a classic Neapolitan pizza eatery, not unlike what you might encounter on a side street in Milano. The restaurant is relatively small, and bustling, so it's best for a casual meal for up to four.

Having tried the pizza on several occasions, I'm down with the 4.5 star average reviews. You'll find a highly reliable, authentic, crispy-crusted, delicately yeasty pizza with just the right amount of "bite" to the crust.

If you're not certain which pie to order, the waiter will readily point you to the burrata Margherita. Enjoy a glass or two of wine while you're there, and walk off your meal with a visit to the nearby Filbert steps, all 400 of them, all the way up to Coit Tower. Don't be a weenie, start at the bottom!!
author: John H.

description: Great authentic Italian food. Service was a little slow but very friendly.  The meatballs were amazing.
author: Mark B.

description: This is the second best pizza place in SF, after Tony's pizza. Tony's doesnt take reservations over the phone, but this place does! You can put your name of the waitlist from yelp app itself. We did that 20 minutes before we made it there. Although when our turn came, we missed it by 5 minutes since we were finding parking, but the server said they would accommodate us next. We had to wait  there for some 15 minutes after which we were given a table. Its a tight place, but very SF-y. The oven is in the middle at the back where everyone can see it. There is a bar seating as well as many small tables, all tucked closed together to have max seating possible. Our server was very nice, she took our order for pizzas, gave us the spicy oil with chillies in it. Pizzas were at the table very soon and they were just AMAZING. We went to margherita pizza and one more with meat, both of them were really nice. The sauce on it was the perfect amount of sour that it should be! After finishing the pizzas, we ordered a tiramisu, which was devoured in flat 2 minutes of arrival. I am definitely going here again and taking my guests here too!
author: Roma M.

description: They don't take reservations anymore, so your best bet is to arrive before 6pm. Seats at the bar = watching the pizza magic happen! During basketball season, they've got the game on (with no sound, so you can still soak up the chill Italian enoteca vibes).
author: Nique F.

description: Came here on a Sunday night was really busy.  Didn't have to wait long to be sit at a table.  Staff was real attentive, but they were hustlin and bustlin.  Music was a little too loud.  Ordered the Prosciutto pizza and it was so bomb!! Ingredients tasted fresh.  You can really get that firewood taste in the pizza.  Not greasy or oily at all.  So good!  I'll be coming back to try their other pizzas for sure.
author: KB B.

description:
Loved it! Delicious thin crust pizza... shared the mortadella (Italian sausage) - thinly sliced! Came with white sauce and pistachios... and of course mozzarella! Definitely recommend it.

Also tried the arancini and beet salad. Both good. 

Place got really busy by 7pm so get here early. 

If you like thin crust, come here.
author: Raj S.

description: As an Italian living in America I was looking forward to eating authentic pizza in San Francisco. We were satisfied with the flavor but it is way overpriced compared to what you get. The flame of the oven is too high and both of our pizzas were burned. Good service, very loud environment.
author: C V.

description:
Got home and stomach is COMPLETELY torn up. Probably won't go back
Bread was fantastic though
author: Patrick D.

description: Goes through the motions but falls short. Understaffed front of house, soggy crust, and underwhelming ingredient quality. And pretty gnarly bathrooms, which are always worrying given that this is the part they LET you see...imagine the kitchen.
author: Andrew H.

description:
Such good pizza, just like Italy. I got the margerita which was perfectly watery and cheesy like it should be. The dough is also amazing.

Also got the cauliflower with chili oil. It was fine but it came out super quickly which means it was just sitting around and they heated it up for us. I wouldn't get it again.

But will definitely be coming back for the pizza.
author: Jenna G.

description:
Il Casaro is absolutely delicious and possibly the best pizza place in San Francisco! I know that is a big statement - but it's that good!

I think what makes each pizza so delicious is that the dough is almost fluffy, and each ingredient, from the sauce to the cheese to the meats, are all top quality. You can't go wrong with choosing because everything is fresh.

The service has also been standout every time I've come - friendly and attentive without being overbearing. Overall, Il Casaro is a gem!
author: Holly L.

description:
I had high hopes for Il Casaro based on all the great reviews... but in the end, it was just another average pizzeria.

3 stars for the beet salad that lacked beets and flavor

3 stars for the grilled shishito peppers that were small and lacked heat

3 stars for the bufalino cheese pizza that was bland

2 stars for the calzone that lacked flavor (starting to see a theme here????)

4 stars for the one saving grace - tuna pizza

Despite the disappointing blandness of the food, service was 5 stars
author: Lee K.

description:
Excellent wood-fired pizza. Creative flavor combinations. Friendly servers (somewhat rare in the City). 

We stumbled on this place in North Beach on Labor Day weekend. The Yelp listing said "no waiting," and sure enough, we were ushered right in to the only remaining table inside. Only took about 30 seconds to understand why there were so many waiting outside -- it was a blast furnace inside. 

OK, we were experiencing the hottest weekend on record, and we were sitting about 10 feet from a food-fire pizza oven --- but they could have sprung for a couple of fans. 

First world problem aside -- the burrata was heavenly. Served with honey and a few fingers of flatbread, and a splash of greens. We followed it up with a housemate sausage/broccoli-rob pie, and a margarita pie. Excellent toppings, decent crust. The margarita had a wonderfully mild New York style red sauce. 

We'll be back - on a more temperate evening.
author: Jim S.

description: We really wanted to give them a 3 1/2 stars, but not an option. The burrata was delicious. For a restaurant called "mozzarella bar" expected more than two choices of cheese.   The pizza was good, not amazing.  The cauliflower was too heavy in the capers.   Staff was nice.  If live in the neighborhood or happen to be in the neighborhood good place to stop for a quick bite and be satisfied.
author: K Two's Mom N.

description: Everything was so delicious!! We started with burrata, calamari skewers, and olives. The burrata was average, it was creamy and had a nice little drizzle of olive oil, and served with some pizza dough. The calamari skewers are a must!! The squid was charred beautifully and not over cooked, the veggie slices were a great addition. The olives were smooth and creamy, and had a drizzle of spicy olive oil. We had 2 types of pizza, margherita pizza was simple and delicious, we dipped it in the spicy olive oil that they have on all the tables. The prosciutto pizza, looked good, but my boys weren't a fan of all the parmesan(personally I would've loved it, but I don't eat meat, so I didn't try it) the restaurant had a great vibe, the service was great, and the food was delicious!! Next time I am in San Francisco I will make a trip back.
author: brittany d.

description: Brings me back to Rimini with their authentic Italian Pizzas and imported burrata. The buffalo mozzarella is soft and fresh and I could taste the San Marzano tomatoes used in the sauce. I knew I was in for a treat when I spotted the bright red light bowl of sauce. This pizzeria is Italian owned and the service is prompt and friendly. In true Italian fashion, I had to try their espresso. Wow. It was sweet, bold and aromatic with a perfect layer of crema. Top it off with a Chinotto!
author: Leanna L.

description:
This place is AMAZING.  The pizza was delicious, the service was excellent and the music was perfection.  

It gets busy so come early.  The owner is a doll and the staff will make you feel like a VIP!
author: amanda c.

description:
Molto bene! You don't need to wait in Tony's ridiculous line to get excellent pizza - the margherita is just as good here, and a better price. I've tried pizza and mozzarella in many areas of Italy, and Il Casaro is just as good as any. Imo this is the best pizzeria in North Beach. 

I had the buffalo mozzarella, margherita pizza, and prosciutto pizza. It's hard to describe the flavor; all I can say is to take my word for it and trust that it's very tasty. The food is comparable to food I've had in Italy. The pizzas are cooked in a wood-fired oven. Sure, many pizzerias in this area have this kind of oven, but few bake it right. Many come out doughy and/or chewy (sorry Piccolo Forno). Il Casaro is just right: thin and soft. 

Bottom line: if you want pizza, don't wait at Tony's (no wait to sit 12pm on Sunday, whereas Tony's had a long line). Save yourself time and go to Il Casaro. You won't be disappointed.
author: Lance W.

description:
We were looking for some dinner on a holiday evening and we had no reservations. I had heard good things about Il Casaro and wanted to try it out even tho it was freezing and there was a crowd of people waiting outside. Luckily we didn't wait too long because the crowds outside were all big groups of 5+ and we were just two so we sat down at the counter after like 15 minutes. Tables were empty and the bar had space but staff seemed to be still figuring out what their game plan was for the big groups. The place has good enough seating but I wouldn't say it was good for groups yet the place was packed with groups of 6+. 

I love sitting at the counter because this way I get to see the big pizza oven, and get to see all the other orders being made. We started our night with a glass of chianti, and a burrata plate.
