The burrata was so delicious! It came with a side of hot pizza bread, arugala and tomatoes. Wonderful way to start our meal. We then shared the pappardelle which was perfectly al dente and possible the widest pasta i've ever seen. It was almost so wide, I started to wonder if I'm eating the noodles that lasagna's made from? Either way the sauce was delicious and i loved the dish. 

The pizza is where we probably went wrong. I loved eating broccoli and sausage pizza in Italy so I was immediately drawn to it on the menu and ordered it. But as I watched the staff make pizzas for other tables I noticed no one else ordered it but us. Everyone else probably knew better because the pizza came out and it was kinda soggy. I'm not sure what made it soggy and kinda flavorless... but it was. I've had better sausage and broccoli pizza before but the pizza dough itself was still really good- chewy and fluffy and just great dough.  I had to soak up the pappardelle sauce with the pizza to add some flavor. 

Overall good experience, friendly staff, lively place, good eats. I'd recommend itm and just order a different pizza next time. I saw a lot of pizzas with arugula and proscuitto on it be ordered. I'll do that next time.
author: Veronica L.

description: Looking for Neopolitan pie, well the one I had here was a perfect duplicate of the one I had Napoli. I guess you can make our own but I suggest the "pre-designed" sections from the menu. Neapolitan and chili oil are on the bar to spice it up. Take it easy with the chili oil it's super spicy and I love heat.
author: Rob B.

description: Amazing pizza, great wine, lasagna, and apps. I recommend the Margherita. Our servers were friendly, too. I would definitely come back!
author: Joni W.

description:
Been going there for 4 years now and this place is simply the best pizza in SF. Period. 
I'm not talking about the shit Americans think it's pizza, this is true pizza. I've been all other Europe (France, Italia, Spain, wherever you may think good pizza is made).
Il Casaro live up to the standard and the iconic napolitan pizza.

I usually get the prosciutto pizza and a tiramisu if I have a sweet tooth.

I tried pretty much every single item in the menu. Go for it, you won't regret.
author: Nathan A.

description:
Stopped by during North Beach fest to escape the heat (which didn't actually work because like all old buildings in San Francisco, this place doesn't have air conditioning) and take a break for some lunch. We got the lasagna, the carbonara, a salad, some fried risotto balls and a mozzarella flight..... Lasagna was great, with a really rich, meaty sauce. The carbonara was impressive-- often times I feel like carbonara feels over wrought-- just too much oil or too heavy with cream or cheese, but they got this perfectly done. The risotto balls were not oily at all, and were able to retain a lot of their flavor even though they had been deep fried. The mozzarella flight I did not really partake in, but my friends assured me that it was the creamiest, silkiest mozzarella that they have had. 

I took off one star because our server didn't really check on us, so it was hard to put in our order or ask for more water, get drinks, etc. I also really liked this place though because it's not pretentious at all and is in the heart of North Beach! It takes a lot to stand out in a crowd, but this place definitely does it.
author: Lai-Nin W.

description:
Outstanding pizza with really fresh ingredients.  Pizza was a tad too salty but overall best pizza I've had in the bay thus far.  Service was decent. Price is super fair for the quality and the crust has got an all around amazing chew. 

4.5 stars.
author: Patrick C.

description: Wow this is my new favorite restaurant in San Francisco. Amazing, fresh ingredients...and so many! You get a heap of prosciutto, cheese, arugula. So good. They also have delicious oils and peppers to put on your pizza or whatever. The best pizza in North Beach, I wouldn't be surprised.
author: Colin S.

description:
Nearly all the restaurants in North Beach are named after famous Italians - Marco Polo, Cristofo Columbo, Mona Lisa - so we figured that a restaurant named not after a person but a food profession was a good choice. Il Casaro a.k.a. The Cheesemaker is a reference to the mozzarella tasting bar that this restaurant is organized around. Rather than the kitschy hanging cured meats, baskets and giant wine bottles of other Italian restaurants, Il Casaro has the fresh, open feel of a modern kitchen. 

We sat at a small table by the open window so it felt as though we were sitting outside but were more protected from the sound, heat and debris of the busy street. My friend and I had just had a drink at Vesuvio so opted for water but they had a really interesting wine and beer list. I would love to come back sometime for a drink and a cheese appetizer. But today, we shared the Margherita pizza with prosciutto and a beet salad. 

The beet salad was amazing. Fresh, delicious, light and flavorful. Several kinds of beets, greens, and cheese and nut crumbles. Really nice. The pizza, however, was a bit of a disappointment. Terribly bland. Despite the prosciutto, it needed salt and I never add salt to my food at a restaurant. The crust was nothing spectacular, nice chew but too much bread, soggy in the middle and not crispy at all. I rarely eat pizza and experiences like this one remind me why. It so rarely lives up to its promise.
author: Angelique L.

description: I went to Il Casaro with very high expectations (mostly built up from Yelp reviews). However, I was not happy with the thin crust margherita that I ordered. The pizza was flavorless and disappointing.
author: Lakshmi R.

description:
I was pleasantly surprised with this small pizzeria. A friend had a craving for fresh mozzarella so we decided on this restaurant. Reminiscent of small cafe / market which happens to serve pizza. The menu is expansive. You can stop in for a quick snack or enjoy a full of meal. 

I ordered the affettati di coppa along with castelvetrano olives to start. The antipasti plate is served with a small bed of arugula and a few slices of warm baked pizza bread. The salad was a bit salty but the remainder of the dish was delicious. Spicy coppa was amazing (perfect portion amount) and the bread was tasty. Almost made me wish we had ordered a small pizza.

The mozzarella was ok. I've tasted fresher buffala but not entirely bad considering many Italian restaurants don't offer this menu option. Castelvetrano olives was fresh and perfectly brined. Overall this place is pretty solid given we were only looking for an afternoon snack. I will definitely be back!
author: Ralph A.

description:
SHOULD BE THE #1 SPOT FOR PIZZA IN NORTH BEACH!

I was randomly craving pizza on a Saturday night and decided to go a step up from delivery and frozen pizza. On top of that, I decided to head to North Beach (which is little Italy in SF).

I was so hungry and determined to find good pizza that I completely forgot that it was the weekend of the North Beach Festival (which means A LOT of people and long wait times- even at 10pm)

Luckily, we found this spot and were quoted about 20 mins for a table for two (this is great in comparison to the first place that we went to that told us they couldn't even guarantee anymore seating even though they didn't close for another 1.5 hours)

We sat at the bar. WARNING: THERE IS AN OPEN FIRE GRILL SO IT GETS KINDA HOT, SO BEWARE!

Ordered meatballs as an appetizer and prosciutto pizza with an egg on top (extra charge $) and both were delicious! Meatballs were to die for and the freshly shaven cheese on top was just the right touch! Once the egg yolk broke, it made the middle of the pizza slightly soggy but this was definitely expected (its YOLK for goodness sake!). The arugula is put on the pizza after it is cooked (they put a lot, so, if you are not a fan order something without arugula.

WOULD DEFINITELY COME BACK!
author: Attiana P.

description: Olives were great. The margarita pizza was a soupy mess. The procutto pizza fell apart when separating the slices.
author: Michael R.

description: Stumbled upon this place the old-fashioned way: I walked by while I was hungry. At just 5:30 this place was packed and the only available seats were at the bar, which was surprisingly spacious and comfortable (sit here if you enjoy watching pizza being made!). My boyfriend and I split a Diavola and it was scrumptious -- the pizza had a bit of a spicy kick and the crust was top-notch. My Italian boyfriend comes from a pizzeria-owning family and he loved this place as well. I'll definitely be back!
author: Elyse W.

description:
I am not big on pizza, but you haven't tried pizza till you've been here:)

DRINK: Not a big selection of beer and wine, but they have really good options. Any of their red wines is a good pair with the pizzas.

FOOD: Try the prosciutto pizza! It is amazing! All of their pizza is made with really fresh ingredients. You can literally taste the freshness. The Kale Caesar Salad was one of the best salads I've ever had. I would recommend trying their calamary, rice balls with cheese, and meatballs for appetizers as well.

ATMOSPHERE: This restaurant is really tight and cramp, but it's honestly part of the aesthetics of the restaurant. The dim lighting at night, aroma of pizza, and loud noises causes an intimate setting. The staff are amazing at what they do.
author: Sophia P.

description: Great pizza, no two ways around it.  Savory toppings, salty cheese and a great crust combine for a mouthwatering palate pleaser.  After you give the menu a glance, be sure to check out the special pizzas written on the wall, there are some very interesting and delicious options hiding up there.  They also sport a nice selection of Italian beer and wine to help wash down their pizza pies.  The space itself is not the largest, so it's entirely possible you'll have to wait for a couple minutes to get a seat (depending what date/time you come in of course).  Il Casaro Pizzeria & Mozzarella Bar is a must visit, local or tourist alike.
author: Jeff H.

description: This place is amazing. The service was great they were extremely nice and professional.  We had the Oven roasted Calamari and zucchini skewers as an appetizer probablythe best Calamari I've ever had.  The prosciutto pizza OMG recommend everyone try it.
author: Emanuel P.

description: The burrata is a must-order. When we tried the bread that came with it, we knew the pizza was going to be divine. They have a lot of great and unique combinations. The one with fried eggplant was 4.5/5 but everything else was at 5/5. Will definitely be coming back!
author: Katherine N.

description: This pizza is the delicious. Definitely a texture unique from the rest. I got the spicy calabrese and my gawd that bugga was so damn good!! The thin dough makes this thing just melt in your mouth. The restaurant is super clean and a cool pizzeria vibe with the huge oven out in the open so you can see the wood fire burning all the flavors around making what I would call an Italian style pizza. So good!
author: Jacob N.

description: Awesome awesone awesome. Love this place. Friday night is packed and there is a wait but the food is worth it and the atmosphere is great for a night out.
author: Johnnyflip04 K.

description:
Been here a few times over the years and the pizza itself is fine. It's not so good that they can just be jerks and provide bad service. 

Tonight I was seated and for 10 minutes nobody came to take my order. When I tracked down the waitress that gave me a menu and asked if she was taking my order she poured me water and said no and walked away, apologizing for the wait. 

Another 5-10 minutes goes by and after making stalker level eye contact with everyone that works there I got up to leave. While leaving the host that sat me was in the way of the door because he was getting a live Yelp review from 3 dissatisfied ladies. I excused myself and walked through. Before leaving I informed the now free host that I sat there for over 10 minutes while nobody came over. 

His response? A "whatever" attitude and mocking me and basically telling me to eff off. Perhaps he was upset from those ladies but I'm officially done ever returning here and you should consider the same until they learn some basic customer service skills.
author: Michael K.

description:
Quality food, quality ingredients, made with care. Francesco knows his stuff. We've spent a lot of time in Italy and he's doing it right. 

Roasted asparagus is a great starter but the best of all is the roasted cauliflower with capers and garlic. The pizzas are done exactly right. This is my favorite Italian place in North Beach, and I keep coming back.
author: Just Another Diner A.

description:
this restaurant served up quality antipasti and wine!
We recommend Parmesan asparagus, cauliflower florets with capers, Atlantic smoked salmon and the eggplant balls
Finish with their wood fire pizza
Will def go back
author: Kirk G.

description:
How do I explain the magnitude of quality for this restaurant in a measly Yelp review?!

You know when you go to the orchestra and there are all these instruments playing in unison and each one of them individually is beautiful but together it's a symphony! That's like the pizza here for your taste buds instead of your ears. Do you get it now?

Five of us went on a Wednesday night. If you're there early enough like 6 to 8 pm I don't think there would be any issues for a table, but then later it started getting a bit busy and some folks had to wait a bit for it to clear out. I'm imagining on the weekends it's pretty packed. 

The pizza is phenomenal. There is no other word for it.

I was starving and got to the restaurant an hour earlier than my friends. I couldn't wait, so decided to have a little appetizer. I ordered what I thought was going to be a tiny plate of meat and bread and it was a huge plate for $4.50! I got the mortadella. AWESOME. All the cured meats comes with argugala, cherry tomatoes and their delicious bread. It was such a great starter and I thoroughly enjoyed even before tasting the glorious pizza! 

For 5 of us, we ordered 6 pies. That's right. 6 pies which means on average every one of us ate more than a pie!? That's insane.

The pizza dough is out of control. You can see on the tear how beautifully it's made. The char is a little bit on the stronger side, but not too much to over power with a smoked flavor. The sauce is absolutely perfect. Tart, but still just enough sweet. And the pizza comes out HOT with cheese falling off if you're not careful. The mozzarella is obviously ridiculously fresh. Both the regular and the burrata. 

Here's what we ordered:

Quattro formaggio 
Burrata x 2
Diavola (spicy salami)
Margherita X 2 

My favorite was the one with the salami because I love meat on my pizza, but everything else was cooked to perfection. The four cheese one is good, and I really enjoyed it but the goat cheese could be a bit intense for some people. 

This climbed to the list of my favorite pizza places in the U.S! Can't wait to come back again and I most definitely will.
author: Priti K.

description:
Tried both the margherita and Norma.  Both were amazing.  The Norma surprised me, I thought the eggplant would be large slices and kind of mushy even if fried but it was cut into bite sized cubes and crispy.  

Their homemade tiramisu was pretty good as well!
author: Stephanie Y.

description: This is our go to for delicious pizza in San Francisco. Delicious wines and appetizers a plenty. Anything they serve with prosciutto, arugula, and fresh mozzarella is a big win for your appetite. You won't be disappointed.
author: Candida B.

description:
People kissing each other on the cheek and speaking Italian is exactly what you'll find at Il Casaro.

It's a modern yet cozy space which makes you forget what country you're in.

Our waiter was a very cool and friendly guy that brought us wine samples when we couldn't make a decision. We went with his recommendation and I'm happy we did.

Though I couldn't get past the fresh mozzarella because of how filling it was, my friend had the pizza and said it was delicious.

My friend accidentally left his credit card at the restaurant, and they were kind enough to hold on to it until the next day.
author: Zarene S.

description: The pizza here is the closest I've had to pizza in Italy. Toni's and Golden boy are good but I'd say they're closer to American style
author: Mike A.

description:
WOW! WOW! WOW! I don't think I've ever eaten so much and not felt overly stuffed. And I just kept eating and eating mostly because I couldn't stop because it was that good and a just little bit bc I was preggers. The dough is light and heavenly that you feel like you're on a cloud while eating. The smell of freshly baking dough when you walk in will always be one of the best smells in the world. The ratio of dough, sauce, cheese, toppings is all perfect. The pizzas were gone in a matter of seconds after they were placed on the table. So of course two more were ordered and then those were gone too. We are a group that can eat for sure! One of the best meals I've ever had in SF! Service was also great - our waiter was fast and very efficient. Price was also very reasonable. Good pizza is hard to find in SF and this place is at the top of our list now.

Update: Went back again a few times, to try out other menu items in addition to the pizza. Let me just say that the meatball appetizer is drenched in the most delicious tomato sauce ever. So delicious in fact that even though I was suffering from some pretty bad pregnancy heartburn, I still sopped it up with bread and ate it all because it was way too good to waste. I was struggling later that night with massive heartburn but it was worth every single bite. FYI the meatballs are super delicious too, but I love love love me some tomato sauce.
author: Lisa D.

description: Perfectly prepared and cooked Neapolitan pizza.  l love prosciutto and arugula pizza and theirs is great.  Washed down with a couple Italian lagers was icing on the cake.  Love the area.
author: Adam B. J.

description: The lasagna with mushroom, butternut squash, and sausage was delicious.  I got to come back to try the pizzas.  Those looked amazing.
author: J W.

description:
I'm Italian. I've tried a dozen Pizzeria's all over the city (specially in North Beach) and this is by far the best and most authentic Italian pizza. I'd rate it very good even if the place was located back home. The menu is filled with a good choice of authentic Italian options (no pineapple pizza).

The dough is crunchy with optimal texture, good selection of original ingredients (they even have regional Italian specialties like Arancini, 'Nduja or Buffalo Mozzarella). As many good places, there's going to be a queue outside.
author: Luca G.

description: Service was really fast. Pizza was OK. We ordered the prosciutto and margarita. You have the char on the edge of the Pizza, but the crust on the bottom was flimsy and soggy. Not my idea of a good pizza. The toppings (cheese and sauce) were very watery so as soon as you pick a slice up it floods the plate and all the sliced get soggy. Boo. Wouldn't go back.
author: Erin A.

description: This place did not disappoint! Wanted some good authentic Italian food at a fun location in little Italy. Loved loved loved the prosciutto pizza and the simple romaine salad we ordered. Wish the pizza would have been cooked for a minute or two more but it was delicious. Definitely would recommend for anyone wanting some pizza.
author: Olivia J.

description: Best pizza and the best tiramisu ever.   We found this place on our penultimate night in SF and went back on our last night.  Don't think we will find tiramisu as good as that again.
author: Oonagh G.

description: Went for lunch and was not disappointed. Their pizza is great: lots of toppings (which are all delicious), and a great variety on the menu. Their crust is fantastic, nicely flakey and slightly charred from the wood fire. It also comes out very quickly after you order, which is another plus. Service was very good, and they had multiple open tables during the lunch rush. Only complaint is the pizza gets soggy pretty quickly. I know that's part and parcel with thin crust pizza, but our group ate pretty fast and we still had soggy pizza with a couple slices to go. Worth the stop, but recommend ordering one pizza at a time and eating family style so your pizza isn't wet when you eat it.
author: Brett B.

description:
Went here for a quick dinner.  Pizza crust was soggy, pasta was okay,  great service.
I'm sure there are many better options in SF for Italian food. Would not come back.
author: Firas D.

description: Tried Il Casaro for the first time last night. It was getting crowded when we got there around 6:00 but luckily got seated right away. They don't take reservations so have to get lucky on busy nights. W started with the olives and burrata! Both were amazing and the bread that comes with the burrata is like a crispy pizza crust flatbread. My husband got the calzone and I got the Il Casaro pizza. The pizza was so fresh and the crust was crispy but also light at the same time. You can see them making everything in the pizza oven. A great local spot with a simple pizza menu and all Italian servers and staff. I'd definitely go back again and again.
author: Carol Ann V.

description:
The food here is so good! Before going to San Francisco, I did some research on Yelp for Italian food and this was 1 of 3 restaurants on my list. My friend who lives in SF recommended I try this place so I did. I arrived at the restaurant around 6pm on a week night and got a table for 2. We were seated right away because it was pretty empty (only 2 other tables filled). They don't take reservations so coming early was part of my plan. 

We ordered the burrata, asparagus, cauliflower, and prosciutto pizza. All of the dishes tasted amazing but I loved the burrata and the prosciutto pizza. I like that they shaved parmesan cheese over some of the dishes. It was a generous amount. For dessert, I ordered the tiramisu. Their tiramisu does not have a strong coffee flavor and I like it that way. The cake was moist and not too wet. It was a nice way of ending the meal.

They're located across from The Stinking Rose. I actually walked on the opposite side of the street so I had to back track to find this place. The inside of the restaurant is a bit cramped and it's not the prettiest looking. Just remember that you're coming here for the food. If you don't want to stand out in the cold waiting for a table, come by 6pm and keep the party small.
author: Anna F.

description:
Saddest pizza I've seen in this city for the last 20 yrs I've lived here!
Took some out of town visitors here tonight on another friend's recommendation.  Photos on Yelp looked like fresh, authentic Italian ingredients.  The pizzas we got were the soggiest pizzas I have ever seen.  The fresh mozzarella on the pizzas was good.  But it doesn't make up for the pizzas being so soggy we couldn't pick up the slice with even 2 hands.  And the cheese slid down the wimpy crust immediately.  I was so embarrassed to have taken my friends here.  

I wanted to show my friends a part of SF that still had the old school charm of the city by the bay.  But this pizza was so sad that I will now go to the multitude of pizza joints around town who know how to make a crispy crust and never-mind North Beach.
author: Lisa T.

description: This pizza is authentic and high quality. The garlic, parm and crust is amazing! Little waiting and service is great
author: Jennifer D.

description: This place is fresh and delicious. I don't know a thing about authenticity. But if it's fresh and tasty, I don't care much about how authentic it is. The pizza was delicious. Fresh, and great care seemed to go into the ingredient choices. Service was efficient and friendly. I'm looking forward to trying their lasagnas next.
author: Jason P.

description: Very good authentic napoli style pizza. Tiny place, but fast kind service. Tried the buffalina which was wonderful, simple and delicious, and the diavola- warning I think they might put some chili oil on it so a bit spicy! Highly recommend
author: Megan G.

description:
Oh a mozzarella bar. I totally get it... that makes so much sense!

The fresh pulled burrata is divine. Love the rich and creamy texture of the cheese, drizzled with some olive oil, and paired with the peppery arugula salad and sweet tomatoes. So simple but so satisfying. We split a couple of pizzas including the Margherita and the Diavola. Tony's up the street probably serves a better pie but the pizzas here are pretty legit too. Nice char on the crusts and the pies hold up well to the toppings. The Diavola pie stood out a little more and I liked the savory balance between the mozzarella cheese, spicy salami, and tomato sauce.

Service is really friendly and charming - some might say borderline flirty but hey, when in an Italian restaurant. Il Casaro has a decidedly younger, contemporary, and more casual vibe than its older counterparts in North Beach which should endure it to locals and tourists alike.
author: Jon L.

description:
This place met my expectation.  We rarely get to go to such good pizza places where we live so on our overnight stay in SF last Sat. night we went with friends to this very metropolitan and hip pizza joint.  The ambiance is very classy and updated.  The super high ceilings make having a conversation difficult when the restaurant is filled and if the music is turned on you'll just have to scream or enjoy a wonderful meal speaking in sign language or not at all.  Tip is to arrive before 6 pm on a Fri or Sat for dinner (for you old fogies like me).  Our waitress was very accommodating by turning the music down.  She was very helpful w/ menu descriptions and keeping tabs on us as more people filed in to dine.  

The food was fantastic!  Two of us shared a kale and romaine Caesar salad which was dressed well (not heavy on the homemade dressing and not too light) and our friends split a beet salad that looked gorgeous and they loved it (golden yellow sliced beets, goat cheese, onions and lettuce). Our pizzas were sooooo good.  I got the Margherita pizza and added arugula lettuce.  To die for!  My partner got a Prosciutto pizza and our friends got a Margherita pizza too and they loved it.  Wood fired pizza using 00 Italian flour high quality ingredients makes the best pizza. 

WE ARE GOING BACK!!!
author: Mindy S.

description: Awesome authentic spot. We came by on Friday night around 7 and grabbed a couple seats at the bar without having to wait, but there were people waiting in line very soon after. The burrata was amazing, good priced wines, and the prosciutto pizza was also great. Definitely recommend sitting at the bar watching the magic happen. Service wasn't amazing but they were super busy and for the price I am okay with it. I will be back!
author: Shabnam E.

description:
Good food and the waitress was lovely.  Busy busy but my beverage was never empty and food was fast.  They offered sparkling or regular water.  

Four stars because it was a bit pricey but Quality over quantity (which was also fine).
author: Becky W.

description:
Food: 5/5       Price:3/5            Service:4/5            Ambience: 5/5

*** MICHELIN Guide 2017 ***

A modern looking Italian restaurant in Little Italy. Probably one of the only few Italian places around here that have great reviews and don't have a long wait. (Tony's and other places are 1.5+ hr) We were seated as soon as we got in, ordered our food, and the pizzas came within 5 minutes :)

The restaurant has its giant open windows to the street, so you can feel the breeze and see the people walking by. Very comfortable and welcoming. If you are lucky, you can even get a seat at the bar counter where you can watch the chefs roll out the pizzas and bake them in a wood oven. 

We ordered 2 pizzas, Prosciutto and Norma. The size was a lot smaller than I expected, based off the price. Both pizza crust were very thin and soggy.  I could hardly pick up a piece without letting all the toppings drip and fall down my hand. However, the flavors were really good. 
 
We especially enjoyed the Prosciutto pizza.  Prosciutto was very flavorful. In addition to the amazing melted mozzarella, the pizza was topped with large pieces of unmelted shredded cheese -  surprisingly good! Norma pizza was a basic Margarita pizza topped with eggplant. Simple flavors, yet delicious. But it was a lot more soggy than Prosciutto pizza....  Along side the pizzas, there were red chili soaked in spicy oil. It was SO GOOD! Gives the pizza a great kick of spice. When you're done with the middle part of your pizza slice, dip the end crust into the spicy oil - trust me, you will leave no crusts behind! 

Overall, fairly delicious pizza restaurant with great atmosphere. It's a great place to go if you cannot bear the wait at the other famous pizza restaurants.  


Favorites: 
* Prosciutto pizza ($18.75) - San Daniele prosciutto, arugula, tomato sauce, mozzarella, cheese

Other orders: 
* Norma pizza ($15.75) - mozzarella, tomato sauce, ricotta salata, fried eggplant
author: Victoria L.

description:
Crust should be crust - crunchy, crispy, snappy or whatever adjective you choose. Not a hot air balloon. This is what I ended with after each slice of pizza. Was it good? Sure. It was alright. It was tasty in fact; with the addition of hot pepper flakes and Parmesan! Would I return? Highly unlikely. 

Shortly after being served the pizza was cold. Their Margarita pizza is floppy and soggy. The Prosciutto pizza was okay. I would have been content with just the prosciutto slices and parmesan slices to be honest. Our wine had to be served in heavy water glasses because they 'ran out of wine glasses'. Not the end of the world. But still. Plus the wine really should have had a moment to breathe for oh.. I don't know, maybe an hour or so. 

Our table of four was situated snugly against a wall of fire logs. Undoubtedly for use in the fire-wood pizza oven. It's a nice decor statement. Except when you're wearing a silk dress, attempting to squeeze in behind the table next to you without snagging. 

The salad was delicious. My favorite item on our table!
author: Jaylena P.

description:
Best pizza out there. Plus the waitress is extremely nice. 
I have nothing bad to say about this place. Its definitely my top favorite pizza spots in the bay area.
author: Evan M.

description: Amazing thin crust pizza! Great atmosphere.  And the wait staff was super attentive. Highly recommend this place for a tasty dinner out.
author: Genoa Y.

description:
Exactly as described on Yelp. Casual, well priced, yummy food and excellent service. 
We went at 7pm on a Friday night. No reservations but you can call ahead and put your name on the list. When we got there at 7pm there wasn't a wait. 
Try the burrata and the meatballs! Ask for recommendations on the wine.
author: Carrie H.

description: Durning a Business trip to Oakland a group of coworkers and I decided to head to San Francisco one night. I stumbled across this place on Yelp and decided to give it a try. OMG!! I am so happy that I did! Everything was amazing. We had the imported burrata and mozzarella in carroza for appetizers and both were so delicious. For the entree we couldn't decide so we decided to order a few pizzas along with lasagna and a calzone. The mozzarella on the pizza was extremely fresh. The crust was perfect. The evening was made perfect by the service. I can't recall the name of our server but she was so friendly and patient with our 20 questions. Her recommendations were on point. I can't wait to visit San Fran again to stop by for round 2!
author: Susie M.

description: Little rustic mordern Italian restaurant in the heart of little Italy. Hip kind of feel modern with a touch of classic Italian. We ordered the half margarhita with sausage and the other half I can't remember the name. All in all, the pizza was just sub par. It was soggy and disappointing to say the least. When I picked up a slice, all the toppings and cheese slid right off. I was really hoping to enjoy this joint but it just didn't cut it for me. Won't be coming back.
author: Norintra L.

description: Best Neapolitan style pizza i have tried in this city. Yelp wants more characters than that first sentence.
author: Winter M.

description:
Disclaimer: my husband and I are both Italian expats - we moved to the Bay Area 2 years ago.

We went to Casaro after hearing every Italian on our Italian expats' group on Facebook praising their pizza. I used to rarely eat pizza even when I was living in Italy, but my husband is a great lover. We went there after the movie theatre where I ate too many pop-corns so I arrived there without any hunger, therefore I decided to order a salad. Ingredients: romaine heart lettuce, roasted pine nuts, olive oil, lemon. Price: $9.5, which sounds crazy, but first, it's San Francisco and, second, maybe it was quite abundant. 

My husband ordered a marinara + mushrooms. It was about 1.45pm.

After a wait of about 40-45 minutes, our plates arrive! In the meantime, I got really hungry and there was no bread or breadsticks to bunch on as we usually have in Italian pizzerias. But that's ok. Unfortunately, beyond a little bunch of romaine heart lettuce leaves, roasted pine nuts, olive oil and lemon, there was grated cheese all over the plate! Wonderful, I can't eat cheese. So I send them back my plate and I order calamari, that cost only 50cents more of my previous choice and are way more nutrient and satisfying. 

Pizza: nope. Slightly burnt at the bottom and in little dots on the perimeter, quite uncooked the rest, yielding a very soft and pillowy pizza, with zero crunchiness. It was also full of black olives - which have a strong flavor, so he removed 1/2 of them - and the mushrooms were simply cremini - in Italy, you almost never put cremini on a pizza. At the end, he said no. We won't return.
author: Valentina G.

description:
when you get a bacon burger,
--- there's bacon in it.

when you get a birthday cake,
--- there's cake in it.

when you get a coffee,
--- there's coffee in it.

this is just how food works.

yet with ingredients listing mozzarella...
in a place called Mozzarella Bar...
my pizza showed up with no cheese.
funny thing to forget in a cheese bar.

my diy burrata x mortadella plate was quite enjoyable. and burrata serving was generous enough that i had extra to smear on the pizza.

both talkative & silent servers were polite. i'd return for more charcuterie but probably save pizzas for $12 happy hour.
author: Dan B.

description:
Fantastic food. Pizza, salad, appetizers, staff is great. The only thing is they blast their
Music way too loud.
author: Bea L.

description: Great traditional pizza!! The staff is very friendly and the brick oven is the main attraction.
author: Miguel G.

description: Was craving a good Margarita pizza and decided to stop by and try it out. The pizza was the bomb. It could have used a little more basil but I'm not complaining, the crust was perfectly cooked, had the perfect chew and the flavor was off the charts. The cheese and sauce proportions were perfect. I know California wines well but not so much on the Italian wines so I took a chance and was a little disappointed in the wine - it wasn't bad, but had an oxidized / vinegar off flavor. Service was good, but not overly friendly. I'd go back for the pizza in a heartbeat, but get a beer or order a bottle of wine over a glass (if I knew the wines they had better). This place is legit.
author: Matthew S.

description: Soggy thin crust pizza that looks awesome...small wine pours in a modern space with a hot oven on display.
author: Dennis W.

description: Very negative experience due to extremely loud music that the waiters were saying could not do anything about because 'the owner wants it this way'. The volume was not bearable for more than 15 minutes, which I suspect had to do with why the owner wanted it that way--quicker table turn over means more revenue when there is always some sucker to walk through the door. This was a Saturday night and I am not sure if other days of the week are better. Oh, the food was average (3.5 stars) but because of to the inhumane treatment due to noise I can't give more than 1 star.
author: Boris R.

description:
This has to be some of the best pizza I've had! Classic Neapolitan Pizza done with great care. So glad I made it here during my long weekend in SF. Let me tell you why Il Casaro was such a great experience... 

For one thing, their wait for a party of 6 was reasonable - about 30minites. We were originally going to go to Tony's, but after we were quoted a 2.5hr wait time we decided to go somewhere else. I had seen good reviews on Yelp for Il Casaro so we made our way over. Upon arrival we put our name on the list. Only 2 parties ahead of us! Score! Finally after about 30mins of waiting we were seated. 

Il Casaro is small... I think the biggest table I saw seated 6 and it was the one we had. I love small restaurants though, so much more intimate. When you walk in you see the huge pizza oven right in the center with the pizza makers right there tossing the dough. So cool to watch them work their magic. 

Once seated we ordered wine and beer - very reasonably priced. Next up we got the burrata appetizer. If you have never had burrata you are seriously missing out. It is amazingly creamy mozzarella! It was served with flatbread, arugula, and cherry tomatoes. So fresh and a great beginning to what was to come. Or party of 6 ordered 3 pizzas: the prosciutto, the buffala, and the broccoli rabe. 

My favorite, hands down was the prosciutto! YUM!! So much prosciutto, delicious cheese, and a fabulous chewy crust. The buffala was a close second. Our whole party agreed though that the broccoli rabe & sausage pizza was a kiss. The flavors didn't mesh well. I'd skip this one if I were you. The broccoli rabe was too bitter, in my opinion. 

Overall this was an exceptional pizza experience in Little Italy. Check this superb place out when you are in SF.
author: Sara W.

description: I'm not really a Italian fare type of person but Il Casaro was really quite something! I had this plain looking Lasagne but man... it was delicious! Portion is not too big like typical American portion and it's great for a light dinner.
author: Paul T.

description:
This is my favorite pizza place in California. It rivals the pizza I've had in Italy and I find myself craving it all the time. The Diavola and Prosciutto pizzas are the best on the menu. The tomato sauce on the pizza is addicting!!! Not too salty or sweet. I will say that the crust doesn't get as crispy as I'd like it to be, but that's the only small thing to note. 

One tip if you're going for a casual dinner with one friend - sit on the bar area and watch them make and crank out the pizzas! So fun!
author: Kat L.

description: Best pizza in San Francisco, just the same as in Italy. I really recommend this place.
author: Anna V.

description: Had the burrata cheese and wild boar for an appetizer. The cheese was perfection, and the plates came with some bread, arugula & cherry tomatoes that were put together so simply with drizzled olive oil, but everything tasted incredibly fresh and delicious. We also ordered a prosciutto pizza & lasagna with butternut squash - Definitely recommend.
author: Jackie S.

description:
I randomly stumbled upon this place and was so glad I did it. I was there with my wife and our little boy. The staff was very friendly and the food was great. Their pizza is amongst the best I've had in the area and the prices aren't crazy. The place itself is really nice too!
I really recommend this place! Oh and try the burrata plate, you will thank me later.
author: Jeferson N.

description:
Consistent in quality! Favorite Pizza spot. Simple menu with delisious choices.
Great customer service and good turnout.
author: Mamuka G.

description:
Wow. This pizza was phenomenal. We ordered the Fried Mozzarella and the Prosciutto pizza. We were not disappointed. 

We were seated immediately. The entire restaurant was booming. Seating was a little tight. The table we were placed almost felt squeezed in, but the staff is extremely nice. If you're looking for a quiet place to eat, this may not be it. But if you're looking for quality food, you've found it.
author: Hannah B.

description: great surprise in the Chinatown area in San Fran. Pizzas are authentic Napoletana and the Mozzarella bar is fantastic! nutella pizza is a must have!
author: Maria Eugenia C.

description:
Authentico and deliciosa! A very harried wait staff may make you think twice, but the quick food delivery and high quality make up for this. 
The pizza was very well presented and tasty. The wine selections were terrific. 
The beet salad was among the best I've had in SF so this will now supplant our stop at North Beach and become our afternoon snack restaurant.
author: David B.

description:
Absolutely loved this place. Pizza was ready fast...had we waited twice the time, it wouldn't have seemed unusual.
Our waitress was super friendly too.
author: Steve A.

description: We had an excellent experience here. We came for an early dinner before a show and had arancini, salad and a bufalini pizza. All of the food was excellent, especially the cheese on the pizza. It was quick, reasonably priced, and delicious.
author: CJ F.

description: Buratta was good, however soggy pizza. Mediocre. Expected better.
author: Rick B.

description: Most of north beach is a tourist mob with high priced mediocre Italian but this place is a gem! Everything is delicious and service is great
author: Jade B.

description: Food was ... alright, but service was lacking, never got the server's name, never got checked on, and she stood talking as I waited for service
author: Jonathan O.

description: Wow!! Our waiter was Rad seriously that is his name and service. We weren't easy. We wanted a specific pizza. It wasn't really what we wanted .. they made a whole new pizza. No judgement, no attitude just no problem. We value our customers. Rad stated we take this seriously. Showing they demand quality of themselves. We were so impressed. Thank you and cheers to the crew!
author: Alison F.

description:
Had dinner here on a rainy Sunday night as we were walking around North Beach looking for a place to eat. Il Casaro on Columbus Ave was among the restaurants that had later hours on a Sunday aside from the usual suspects that have sidewalk dining. We looked at the menu outside and decided to try it out. First impression aside from a semi-busy crowd for a late Sunday night is how warm the room is because of the wood fired pizza oven. It definitely warms up the room. But even on a cold night like that, it was still a little too warm for my liking. 

We were seated at one of the high tables towards the back side of the space. Our server was attentive and friendly and knew when to leave us alone & when to ask us if we needed anything. We started off with some mortadella which was served with some crostini, arugula and roma tomatoes drizzled in olive oil. It was excellent. The mortadella along with the crostini and greenery were great. It had great flavor and was a perfect appetizer. 

The pizza we ordered was the broccoli & salsiccia. It came with italian sausage, broccoli rabe and mozzarella cheese. The crust was good, the cheese was great, so was the italian sausage but the broccoli rabe was just too bitter to my liking. I dont think I would get that pizza again. They have several other choices that I would rather try out. 

Il Casaro was a nice option for a casual meal in North Beach. Street parking only. Open late. Good service. Decent food.
author: Chuck D.

description: I think this place is pretty top notch. Proper Neapolitan pies, Italian waitstaff, inexpensive beer and wine menu--checks all the boxes. Further, it's not a nightmare to get into unlike seemingly everywhere else in SF. My girlfriend and I specifically loved the diavola pizza and the asparagus with shaved parm. The reason it's not 5 star for me is because 2/3 into our meal our very-otherwise-lovely waitress left without telling us and it seemed that none of the other waitstaff was informed either, which added about 10 minutes of confusion and attention seeking on our end. Other than that blip we loved it and would gladly go again.
author: Ryan J.

description: Perfect Italian pizza. As simple as that. By the way, I'm Italian. Cool place, friendly staff and great food.
author: Francesco C.

description:
Authentic Italian cheese and pizza selections here. Today I tried:
-Burrata($9): cheesy, creamy,specially imported from Italy, and served with arugula, cherry tomatoes, and bread. This was a good appetizer. The consistency of the cheese was perfect!

-Proscuitto pizza($17): consists of ham, arugula, and topped generously with cheese. Pretty good pizza.

One thing I noticed was that they serve broccoli pizza here! I never knew about that until the movie Inside Out.

I would give 4 stars but I'm giving 3 because when I called twice before coming in, someone picked up the phone and hung up twice in a row. Not professional guys!
author: Corinna T.

description: Best pizza I've ever had. Not greasy at all, cooked to perfection. You really can't go wrong with any of them, and the appetizer are delicious. I'd stay away from the cream soda though, not really the tastiest beverage there.
author: Usman P.

description:
One of may favorite places in San Francisco!  Everything on the menu is amazing!!! great pizzas!  Nice atmosphere and friendly staff.
i definitely recommend!!!
author: G R.

description:
Thank you to Janice C. and Sebastian F. for taking us here with you! What a find. 

This casual restaurant specializes in wood-burning stone oven baked Neopolitan style pizzas. Don't expect a plethora of pizza toppings. Here, it's all about delicious simplicity. 

We ordered the popular Diavola pizza with fresh mozzarella and tomato sauce. The spicy salami topping that adorned the pizza was oh so savory. The basic dough crust was delicate and crisp on the exterior and supple on the inside. Yum. My favorite pizza out of the two we tried that evening. 

The burrata was heavenly---a must order. It was rich in flavor, unlike many bland ones I've encountered at other places. 

Don't leave without ordering the raspberry panna cotta, to end your evening on a sweet note. Creamy, subtly sweet with luscious vanilla flavor. 

Great service; you'll feel right at home. Enjoyable ambiance.
author: Merica S.

description: Too noisy. The taste is great. The service is great. It is too hot to eat here. The price is high. The seat is small. Hope to have AV.
author: 欣姵

description:
Finding great pizza isn't an easy task in any US city.  Fortunately we stumbled upon Il Castro's wood fire pizza and mozzarella bar while walking in North Beach!  The place is casual with attentive/friendly/competent staff.  We ordered the San Daniele Prosciutto and Pizza Margharita, both of which were ultra fresh and so tasty!!  Haven't had pizza this amazing since I returned from living in Rome.  AhMazing!!!  If you plan to visit San Francisco add this spot to your list of "must experience" eateries... you won't be disappointed!!

Buon Appetito!!
author: Donna V.

description:
Really yummy pizza in North Beach and probably the best I've had in SF. I can still taste the pillowy cloud of dough in my mouth. Also, it's pretty authentic from the looks of how many Italian Italians were there in the joint while I was eating. The pizzas are about $20 each and I think half is pretty filling for one meal. Service is quick, and I'd recommend sitting next to the oven at the bar. Kinda cool to see the pizzas being made.

Also, order the burrata! It's heavenly...
author: Cindy W.

description:
If the waiters here are Italian, that means it's legit right?

I came here after work once and ordered pizza with wine. The pizza was thin crusted, and the toppings plentiful. You can tell they use high quality ingredients. 

My favorite thing about this place though is the ambience - suitable for a friend gathering or to come with your SO.
author: Vivian W.

description: Wow this place is amazing. Recently had a late lunch here with my boyfriend and his parents. His dad tends to be a little picky and this had something for everyone and was the a great restaurant for everyone to share food and stories. Lively and quaint environment with the most AMAZING pizza and fantastic appetizers. Service is superb and selection of food is easy and made in a timely manner for each table. I can't wait to come back again shortly.  Me and my boyfriend are constantly planning trips here to much down on some yummy pizza, cauliflower and cheeses!
author: Casey P.

description:
Dinner review. 

Buffalo mozzarella - 3/5
Boar salami - 2/5
I'll casaro pizza + egg + sausage - 4/5

Overall, "A-OK."
author: Mark O.

description:
Excellent pizza and atmosphere 
I see this as a usual pizza spot. really everything i tried was top notch
author: Sarah H.

description:
This lil gem is located in the Russian Hill area & there are many Italian places around there as well. I'm so glad I chose this place! And it was a short walk from my hotel.
There was a crowd of people outside waiting to be seated, but because I was dining alone, I was seated right away at the bar. Absolutely appreciate that. I could see how the pizzeros, or pizza makers, made the delicious pizzas.
I ordered the margherita pizza & it was so incredibly delicious, I ate the whole thing too! (Don't judge, I was carb loading for a 5K!) They brought carafes/bottles of water to the guests & small glasses to pour into.
I also ordered a Mexican coke. 
Everything was very good. The service was attentive, the atmosphere was casual & lively. Really, everything a good dinner experience should be. The price was reasonable as well. 
I'll be back. I'm sure.
author: Lili L.

description:
Fresh pizza eatery in North Beach.  The ambiance is welcoming and dining is of pleasant demeanor.  

Open, airy windows and outdoor seatings available.  We ordered up their prosciutto, arugula Neopolitan pizza and it was nice.  I liked their mozzarella margherita basil pizza more.  Maybe it was just that day that I preferred it.  Otherwise, I usually like my savory and salty prosciutto.

Ordered up their meatballs and it was good.  Their octopus pasta was different and spot on a feasible dish.

I like the contemporary feel of this place - it lightens up the old school shops in North beach neighborhood.
author: Tiffany D.

description: Great place, very authentic and amazing food and great staff. The wait can get quite long but it's certainly worth it. Do yourself a favor and try this gem of a restaurant. 5 stars no question. Thanks il Casaro!
author: Bob S.

description: Love this place. The prosciutto pizza is to die for. Everyone who works there hustles because its so busy. The service is fast and friendly. Thank you Alex and Alexa for the laughs, great service and excellent recommendations.
author: JR P.

description: By a stroke of luck I found this little gem and it's all thanks to one of the servers getting a Lyft ride with me and accidentally leaving his phone behind in my car. It led to me tracking him down at work at Il Casaro and taking home a pizza. My friends and I loved the pizza so much, and we were still hungry, that we came back for another pizza, wine and dessert! The atmosphere is fun and relaxed, the servers are super friendly and the food is top notch! Sometimes things do happen for a reason and I'm so glad my chance Lyft ride encounter led to this! Will be stopping by anytime I'm back in SF and will be telling all my friends about it too!!
author: Michelle P.

description: This this restaurant is an excellent example of perfectly executed  restaurant and pizza restaurant. In my opinion, IL Casaro' is unmatched in quality and taste.
author: Sam C.

description:
3.5 stars, rounding to three to bring the Yelp average back to Earth. Rather bland interior, bland customers (mostly tourists), bland, business-like service (not at all bad, just bland). Pizzas were, well, rather bland - though, I again emphasize - not bad, and fairly priced, with well made dough. 

Staffing is typical for the area - couple of cute chicks in the front of the house; compact Mexicans working hard in the business end. 

Highlight for me was the beer, 2 IPAs on tap for just $6, one the obvious Lagunitas (no arguments there, it's the only beer in my fridge), and a second excellent one I ordered and promptly forgot the name of. Overall, despite the 3/5 given, I would return.
author: Nick C.

description: Came here with a group of 12 and they accommodated us within 10 minutes. Our group was being a bit difficult with what we would do to order, but we split the group in two and had a great time. Our side of the table (seven people) got 3 pizzas as well as the Brussels sprouts. I asked the owner what the best three pizzas were and to bring them. They were incredible. There was a spicy one, one with a ton of prosciutto, and another more simple one with mushrooms. The Brussels sprouts were tasty and our group (of seven) had a great time!
author: Jake A.

description:
Every time, and I mean EVERY TIME I visit San Francisco I make the pilgrimage up Russian Hill to Il Casaro.  
Why?
Because they have the best pizza in San Fran, hands down.  I know people fall into a few camps regarding pizza (deep dish, thin crust, etc), but I have never known anybody to taste Il Casaro's pie and say, "Meh."  It's usually more of a wide-eyed "Holy cow!" sort of look on their faces.
The wizards at Il Casaro crank out these thin crust delacies right in front of you, the maw of the pizza oven angry and orange.  The skilled cooks hustle the pies in and out, each pie exiting the oven with a perfect amount of charred blistering on the crust.  Their sauce is a study in delicious simplicity.  The toppings are very fresh, and the cheese, ah the cheese.  You could lure me off a cliff with their cheese.
Take all of that, pair with a decent beer list, plunk it all down in a pumping area of the city, and you have Il Casaro  - a pizza joint worthy of pilgrimage.
author: Dan O.

description: Very bomb dough. Love the style-crust. The tuna version is simply divine. Assume the other ones are of a similar quality. Owner and staff are bright, enthusiastic and personable and seem like they like working together and with their customers. All in all, a winner. Recommended
author: Juls C.

description: Lively atmosphere and service, plus one of the best pizza I have ever had. Perfectly cooked with generous amount of toppings
author: Sandra A.

description:
This place gets it right. Napoli pizza is not meant to be fancy, it's street food. The focus is in the quality of ingredients and the technique in its creation. Il Casaro is the most authentic Neapolitan pizza joint in San Francisco. Super friendly service and pizza that is out of this world. 

Know that this style is different. Don't go in looking for your local pizza joint. One person could eat one pizza. But the flavor is incredible.

I love sitting at the bar and watching them work. Highly recommended if looking for great food in San Francisco!
author: Ryan B.

description: Their MDUJA sausage pizza and meatballs were great! They had a sign-in sheet with a few names when our group got there, but we were still seated right away. Definitely going back.
author: Enrique A.

description: Friendly service, clean place. However, Too loud in here, I couldn't hear the waiter and ended up mishearing a menu item causing me to get the wrong dish. Lasagna bianca is too greasy, like a cheese rock. Couldn't eat much of it. Should've tried the pizza instead. Would not recommend. In hindsight, should've left when we saw the menu. More hipster than anything else.
author: Katie C.

description:
After finally trying out the pizza at Il Casaro, I think it deserves a review update since my last review only had me trying their Salumi Plate and Burrata.  Ate here for dinner with a few friends and we ordered a couple of pies along with their Buffala Mozzarella

Buffala Mozzarella --  http://bit.ly/1AZTDQZ
Like their Burrata this was served with arugula, cherry tomato and bread.  This was very good!  Nice and creamy with a smoked flavor.  Though I still prefer their Burrata, you can't really go wrong with any of Il Casaro's cheese selections.

Diavola -- http://bit.ly/1CZoegJ
mozzarella, tomato, spicy salami
This seems to be the most popular pie at Il Casaro.  And it's a really good one.  It's a simple pie, but the spicy salami does shine and gives the pizza the spicy kick it needs.  This was my favorite out of the two pizzas we had.

Capricciosa -- http://bit.ly/1AZT3md
San Marzano tomato, mozzarella, artichoke, black olives, prosciutto cotto, mushrooms
This pizza didn't hit out of the park for me.  It might have been the mix of toppings used which made the pizza very watery and when taking out a slice the toppings would all slide off.  On paper it sounds delicious, but it didn't taste that good for me.  It's possible though I may try this pizza again in the future.

And for dessert, we shared a Raspberry Panna Cotta.

Raspberry Panna Cotta -- http://bit.ly/1EXLhNH
You really can't go wrong with any Panna Cotta.  I'm a huge sucker for it.  And Il Casaro's was delicious!!  Just the right amount of sweetness from the creamy gelatin and raspberry compote.

So after having a full dinner service at Il Casaro, I still think it's a solid 4 star pizza joint.  I didn't thoroughly enjoy every pizza I had but their pies are still solid nonetheless and their burrata is incredible!  I enjoy the casual atmosphere and they always seem to have tables open which makes it a great spot if you're in North Beach with a few friends and don't have any dinner reservations for the night.
author: Rodney H.

description: This shit is crap I bought a whole pie to my discuss the bread is like PETA bread it's some kind of freak show.   ..... Zero zero is this type of place but gud fud
author: Iz F.

description: My daughter and I had a wonderful lunch here. The beet salad, mozzarella bar and the il Casaro pizza were all delicious. Will definitely be back the next time I'm in the North Beach neighborhood.
author: Roshan L.

description: This place is amazing! The staff is very friendly as well. Glad we took our servers recommendations but I don't remember what we ordered!
author: Rachel B.

description:
That sh!t was amazing!!! Such fresh, creamy, melt in your mouth mozzarella... just talking about it makes me want to turn around and order another mozzarella ball from the bar to go! The waiter and host was very welcoming for it being my first time. I sat at the bar infront of the chef and he was also very cool and struck up a quick friendly convo which wrapped up the whole experience to make it a 5 star in my book!
They effortlessly made a new regular customer and will definitely recommend :)
Thank you for a great ending to a hectic work day!
author: Julio T.

description:
Delicious and authentic Italian food.

This restaurant is located in the heart of SF's Little Italy. There are tons of comparable restaurants around, but this one is sure to please your palate.

We came here based on a friend's recommendation, and it did not disappoint. The interior is quaint...there's an open bar area and a visible pizza oven. They also have a couple of tvs in case you want to catch the latest game or fight.

My fiancé and I ordered the spaghetti carbonara and buffalina pizza to share. We also ordered buffalo mozzarella and prosciutto to share with the table. Everything was delicious. I particularly enjoyed the buffalo mozzarella. It was so fresh and creamy and was delicious paired with the prosciutto and arugula. The spaghetti was equally delicious although the portion was kind of small. I loved the crispy bits of pancetta. The pizza was my least favorite. The crust got soggy really quickly, but it had good flavors.

Service, however, was on the slow side. We also had to remind our servers a couple of times what we ordered. I was told that this isn't typical from my friend who is a regular. It may have been due to the holiday (we went on New Year's Day).

It's definitely worth checking out!
author: Claudia C.

description:
After the Chinatown bar crawl, we needed food. We walked in on Friday, August 7th around 11pm for dinner. Our group of four didn't have reservations. Luckily we got seated right away.

Food:
*Cavolfiori: roasted cauliflower, capers, garlic ($8)
*Asparagi: roasted asparagus, raspa dura cheese ($8)
*Buffalo mozzarella: served with arugula cherry tomato, bread ($9)
*Lasagna: lasagna with bolognese and bechamel sauce ($16)
*Il casaro: mozzarella, grana padana, cremini mushroom, prosciutto crudo ($16.50)
*Affogato ($5)

The cheese was delicious! I love buffalo mozzarella. I wish we had ordered the burrata as well, but I don't think we would have been able to finish it. Maybe an excuse to go back? The asparagus was roasted nicely. The pizza crust was soft with a nice chew and I loved the mushrooms. I'm not a big pasta or cauliflower person, but everyone seemed to enjoy those dishes. The affogato looked great, but I was too full to try it.

Drinks:
*Double espresso ($3)
*Americano ($3)
*Pitcher of beer ($20)

We of course washed everything down with a pitcher of beer. What better combination than pizza and beer? Their espresso did the trick as we were headed to another stop after this. I needed some caffeine!

I loved Vicoletto when I went. Il Casaro was is a great, more casual version. Next time I have to get the burrata though! And of course, try more pizzas!
author: Elena N.

description:
A must for pizza in the city. Definitely better than the overrated Delfina.

This place is very casual, hence the "pizza bar" terminology. Great vibe, great pizza and decent pricing.

Service is fast, casual and friendly. 

All in all, it deserves 5 stars.

Bravo!
author: Mr. Food G.

description: The pizza was pretty fair but the service below average. The manager likes to push people out almost and I kind of get it since there are lines of people outside waiting but there is only one bathroom in the whole rest. which makes the process of going out longer than normal. It takes more time to wait for the bathroom than for the pizza.
author: Jose D.

description: Great little spot! The food was delicious! We had the Italian salami pizza and a Caesar salad. They were both amazing! The restaurant was kinda small and tight but no biggie. When we first got there we had to wait but the wait wasn't too bad. Loved the atmosphere and the music they played. They also had the basketball game going on for the fellas on several flat screens. Only thing I didn't like and the only reason im giving it a 4 star instead of 5 was the fact that we got our salad after the pizza :/. I think the waitress forgot and put it in once we reminded her.  Other then that I loved it and will return on my next visit.
author: Kathy M.

description:
The pizza here is INCREDIBLE. They put that wood fire oven to good use for sure and the fresh mozzarella was a tasty touch. I also got meatballs which were both substantial and delicious.

Another cool thing is if you sit in the bar area you get a nice view of the chefs expertly rolling and kneading the dough for crusts and working the fire oven. It's quite appetizing as well as puts you in the mood for Italian food.

I really wanted to give this five stars, but for one thing that was bugging me the whole time. The stark and glaring juxtaposition of the hardcore rap/hip hop music blaring overhead. Because nothing says authentic Italian food like the soothing croon of Rihanna and Drake. Also, there aren't many seats so you'll be in for a long wait during peak hours.

Other than that. The food is Italian perfection.
author: Destini M.

description: This is, perhaps, the best pizza I've had in San Francisco. All of the ingredients were fresh and top-notch. The crust was done to perfection. I can't recommend this place enough!
author: David S.

description: Phenomenal Neapolitan pizza. One of the top 3 I have had outside of Italy and we go to many Neapolitan pizzerias.  Most aren't worth the time to review but this one was great and deserved the 5 stars. The sauce was wonderful, dough was delicious, and it was cooked to perfection. Not very easy to find a perfectly cooked pizza that is still "wet" in the middle and crispy on the bottom and crust.
author: Dave C.

description: First off, when you walk in it has a modern Italian vibe. When I saw this I had my doubts on the authenticity of the food. Not knowing what to order we asked our waiter who was more than happy to help out with recommendations. They were spot on to what we were looking for. I ordered the Diavola pizza which was phenomenal. The pizzas are perfect size for a single person or to share with someone. In total, the food was more authentic and flavorful than we expected. I would definitely recommend to anyone looking for a great Italian food.
author: Tony A.

description: Their pizza is legit out of Naples. Best pizza in SF. Meatballs also delicious. Not as impressed with the calamari. It's loud so it's kid friendly. The whole family enjoyed it. We will be back!
author: Melissa I.

description:
I'm in love with their Margherita. Perfectly chewy/charred crust, tangy sauce, LOTS of milky mozzarella, just enough basil, wet center (yes, I prefer a wet Naples styled pizza - the way it's supposed to be, over a dry one) and perfect size for one so you do NOT have to share.  

The pizza, needless to say did not last long.
author: Esther A.

description:
Simply delicious pizzas & salads. Everything made with the very best ingredients. Pizzas were of the same caliber as the best we had in Italy.
Couldn't have been happier with the experience.
author: George Y.

description:
Best pizza in the city hands down. Low key setting but food was excellent and it was very well priced. 

Will be back 100%.
author: Ben G.

description:
MOLTO BENE! I've traveled Italy several times and I always love finding the authentic taste this side of the pond. The hundreds of favorable Yelp reviews caught our eye and the food and service (Grazie, Tania) will bring us back. 

What our party of five enjoyed: asparagi, spicy coppa, burrata, castelvetrano olives, spaghetti carbonara, diavola, al salmone and prosciutto pizzas, and for our dismount... tiramisu and affogato. We all loved this place and can't wait to return!    

~ Patrizio at ForTheLoveOfItaly.com
author: Patrick K.

description: With so many places to eat in San Francisco, how do you pick one?  We picked this one since it was in walking distance and it had the words Mozzarella Bar in the name.   Il Casaro, you are a hit with our family!   We loooved the Margherita pizza.  The flavor was great and the crust was perfection.  We also had some delicious burrata cheese, asparagus, and lasagna.   We also had the Bufalina pizza, but frankly, I couldn't really tell the difference between it and the Margherita.  Maybe I was too full!   We sat at the bar, and it was a treat to watch those master pizza makers showcase their craft.  Thanks for an outstanding meal!
author: Kathy W.

description: I'm staying in San Francisco for a few days and this has to be my favorite restraunt so far. I ordered the calzone and it was really good. The service is fast and really friendly my server went into detail about the different type of cheeses they offer in certain entrees which I thought was really cool.
author: Nyomie O.

description: The pizza and lasagna were DELICIOUS! The sauce is to die for! The reason they get one star is because I got grossed out when the cute little Hispanic looking waiter was counting out change and decided to use a clean plate to count out the cash. He picked up the cash, then proceeded to leave the plate at the counter where he seated a customer who ate from it. Yes, I mentioned it to the cook. No no no.
author: Lauren D.

description:
You know when you go to a restaurant so many times that you're bound to have a bad night? Well this finally happened to me last night and I was oh so sad!

I made almost bi-weekly stops at Il Casaro for dinner - making sure I get my Napoli-style pizza and Burrata fix. To this day, I have no complaints about the quality of the food, however, the state of the service last night was thoroughly disappointing.

We arrived at 8:30PM last night, figuring we would miss the dinner rush - wrong! This place was packed, and for good reason, of course. We added our name to the list of waiting patrons, and waited for about 30 minutes. To pass the time, we browsed the Il Casaro's Yelp page and noticed that their was an open reservation for a table at 9:30PM that same night. We decided to book that in case we would have to wait longer (smart right). Wrong. When 9:30 finally rolled around I went inside and informed the hostess of our reservation.  The hostess simply told me NO. and then repeated that and said: "No, you did not have a reservation. No. No. No." No questions asked. Even though we had confirmation that we made one. Luckily, right at that time, a table opened up and we were next on the waiting list, so we got a spot. 

We sat down browsed the menu and I settled on ordering what I always do: aperol spritz, burrata, and the prosciutto pizza.  Sadly, there was no aperol available last night, the aperol supplier had gone MIA - weird! We then ordered our appetizers and our main courses and excitedly waited for our food to arrive and boy did it arrive quick! Our pizza arrived within 5 minutes of ordering it....however our appetizers were nowhere in sight. We politely asked the waitress, thinking maybe she had forgotten, but no...they just weren't ready yet. We waited 15 minutes more, finishing most of our pizza before our appetizers ever arrived. I guess it doesn't really matter in which order you get your food, but when I order the appetizers first, I usually want to enjoy them pre-meal. A friendly warning and apology would have been nice as well. 

Other than the state of the customer service last night, I always enjoy the food at Il Casaro. I'm sure the staff were overwhelmed with all the hungry, impatient guests. I just hope that next time they are a bit better equipped to deal with the situation.
author: Aletta B.

description:
Excellent pizza, pizza crust and mozzy.  The crust is that nice and chewy napolese pizza crust, not "crusty" at all.  What we ordered:

il casaro pizza
prosciutto pizza
margherita pizza
imported burrata mozzarella
buffala mozzarella
Prosciutto plate
spicy coppa plate

The Burrata and prosciutto pizza were my personal favs.  They put a very generous amount of prosciutto and shaved parm on top of the pizza. (see pics).  Half the restaurants on Columbus are a northbeach tourist trap, but this new spot is not one of them.
author: Spencer W.

description: Hands down, some of the best pizza I have ever eaten. They have authentic Roman-style wood-fired brick oven pizza. Their fresh buffalo mozzarella is very high quality, and shouldn't be missed. There can be a bit of a wait if you go during prime dining hours on a Friday or Saturday night, but once you're seated they will get you your pizza very quickly.
author: Steven K.

description:
The lasagne was good, very savory and meaty. However, it was not heated for long enough and there was a bit that was still cold. The waitress was attentive and fixed that by reheating it. 

The atmosphere was casual and pleasant, and the mozzarella appetizer was spot on.
author: Leeyen R.

description:
Still leaving the rating at 5, but there was one blemish with our most recent visit.  The food here is REALLY good and very reasonably priced.

We ordered the roasted cauliflower and it was delicious.  The Calabrese pizza was really good, but after slicing it up it was underdone a little in the middle.  Next time I will check--I wished I had asked them to put it the oven again.   But the toping was delicious as was the crust that was cooked.

The tiramisu was just okay.  The tiramisu at Cafe Greco is better.
author: Bob F.

description: Love this place! Prices r reasonable, they make the pizza fresh right in front of you! I had the margherita pizza and the lasagna and both were so delicious! Wanna come back and try more!
author: Uriae W.

description: Really liked the squid and the tuna pizza, though there could have been more tuna on it.
author: Eric W.

description:
All I can say is WOW. If you like Italian food this is a must!

Had a super enjoyable meal here tonight. The burrata to start. Then the pasta carbonara and the prosciutto pizza. The pasta is made with house made noodles. I highly recommend all three of those items.

We had tiramasu for dessert. It was good, but I prefer the tiramasu at Stella's pastry up the street.

Five stars. Looking forward to returning sooner rather than later. Reasonably priced. Thanks Yelp for a great 4th of July find!
author: Jasmine B.

description:
Wow, such great pizza!

Really simple ingredients, but amazing, authentic pizza.  I've tried a few different pizzas, but my favorite was a vegetarian which was really incredible with quality ingredients and fresh flavors.

This is a great casual , but lively spot for great food...definitely one of the best spots in North Beach!
author: Ken G.

description: Excellent pizza joint, true Italian ingredients and great pizza dough. Good service and nice place for a casual meal
author: Carlos V.

description:
So so so good. Every time I'm in San Francisco for a work layover and I'm craving pizza, there's no other choice for me. This place is the real deal. I also love that the entire staff and most of the customers around me are almost always actually speaking Italian! Delicious food, and great/friendly staff--A real gem in Little Italy. 

Their Diavola pizza is delicious--add arugula to it for just the perfect slice. Can't go wrong here. Buon appetito!
author: Megan O.

description: We were looking for a good pizza and found this place on Yelp with many good reviews. We walked from our hotel, which was about 17 min walk. After walking through the back side of China town, here was Little Italy! We were lucky that we got in before the crowd started to show up. We ordered Margarita pizza, which is very traditional pizza of Neapolitan style.  I wanted to go with a simple one to really taste a good crust. Indeed, it was amazing crust with non-cooked sauce (Neapolitan style). I highly recommend this place if you are looking for real pizza.
author: Mikae Y.

description: Amazing, amazing, amazing!!!!! Still the best pizza place i have ever been to. Their burrata and their pizza. Mmmmmm. This place makes me want to go to San Fran. I wish they would open in LA and the OC.
author: Sam B.

description:
When you do not want to wait three hours at Tony's Pizza Napoletana, go here. The wait is not as bad, I'd say 5-10 minutes wait on Friday night despite the limited seating.

Soon as you get seated, you'll hear a bunch of Italian people, that's how you know you're in the right place for some legit Pizza in the Bay Area. 
Few minutes after the server took your order, drop everything and prepare your camera for an ultimate photo of pizza making show, dough tossing up in the air and all.
author: Liberty A.

description:
I echo comments that the burrata is a must-try. The prosciutto pizza was delicious, the crust, incredible.  Beer is served by glass and pitcher. 

Small restaurant (one restroom) with limited seating but they take reservations. Good for 2-4 people, parties over 6 may find seating challenging but totally worth it regardless.
author: Eliza C.

description: Great service and awesome location. The staff are kind and courteous. I had the margarita pizza and it was excellent. Highly recommend this place for anyone who loves food.
author: Rex D.

description: Everything I ate was quickly followed by, "This is one of the best pizzas... lasagnas... calamari... cauliflower (YES! Cauliflower)... panda cotta...I've ever had." I've never been a big fan of Italian food but that changed today. Thanks for an amazing meal!
author: Shawna B.

description:
Good pizza, good vibes. 

There are lots of great things about this place that deserve mention - friendly staff, wine, mozzarella, beautiful open kitchen, authentic stone fire oven - but for me the conversation starts and ends with the pizza. 

After a lot of internal debate about what to order after looking at the menu (I was surprisingly hit with a chronic bout of decision paralysis after first glancing), I ended up going with the Prosciutto pizza which. was. fantastic.

While the meat was thinly sliced and absolutely delicious, it turns out that no matter what pizza I picked I couldn't have gone wrong. That's because all of their pizza is made the right way -- in a magnificent wood fired oven -- which leaves each one coming out perfectly cooked and ready to be devoured. In addition to using traditional methods, their ingredients are also extremely fresh, generously piled onto each pizza, and perfectly complimentary to their crusts which are slightly chewy, slightly crunchy, and entirely delicious.

(Side note: I focus on the pizza because to be honest - I wasn't a huge fan of the burrata. But that stuff in general just kinda weirds me out, so it would be unfair to knock them for that. I'm just not a burrata guy it seems.)

Anyway, again the pizza here is truly fantastic. I actually think I finished my entire pizza in less than 10 minutes, and I wasn't even that hungry. It's just that good - somehow even BETTER than the pictures, which already make things look mouthwatering. You just need to try it.

Finally, I recommend sitting near-enough to the kitchen area so that you can watch their chefs go to work. It is truly an experience watching their expert pie-makers go about their craft. You can see the prosciutto as it's being thinly sliced into delicious ribbons that pile gently into delicious layers onto a pizza that's - quite literally - fresh out the oven. And when you realize that the pizza you are watching is about to come your way, I guarantee you that you will never be happier that you today is the day you decided to drop into Il Casaro and see what all the fuss is about.
author: Brian S.

description: Looking for place to eat in San Francisco that open a bit late.  This is great place to go. Not only they great food they great service too. Don't forget to safe room for dessert, love panacotta.
author: Pryo H.

description:
Pizza was alright. Had a great portion to have taken home, we actually gave it to our Lyft driver. Great toppings, nice date spot, I feel like I wanted more authentic Italian feel to it. It felt modern and gentrified. They did mess up on our order twice but they fixed it with quickly so no complaints about service. 

I believe we went in for a seafood (shrimp and some other seafood) pizza but that was apparently for a limited time, they don't serve it anymore after seeing great reviews from so many other people.
author: Edward P.

description: If you want to taste an authentic Italian pizza, this is the place. We had a Margherita and a Bufalina: great!
author: Valentina Z.
